author: BatMeckley

Last night I had a question about an audio routing program and multiple people that are not on my payroll, they do not work for me or owe me anything, responded not just same day but within minutes with information that helped me get to where I was trying to go.

author: bobby k

It ended up being a major positive because I was able to say yes to several things that came up since (which included two of the coolest opportunities I’ve had all year, one with producing for a new fav artist of mine and the other with a band I listened to a ton as a kid). author: BatMeckley
content:
So, early in working with Cavallo we we’re doing a project at Skywalker Ranch in Nor Cal, living there for about 6 weeks. And he would unwind by cooking the staff these huge dinners in the industrial kitchen and then when they all retired for the night he would crack a bottle of wine and just talk shop with me for an hour or two. One night we’re talking about mixers, and I mentioned doing a project with another producer where one of the big big big name mixers had tanked the record. And he said “well whose fault is that?” And I responded the mixers obviously, it was awesome when we sent it to him. And he said “no, with all due respect, it’s the producer’s job. I sent back *grammy winning record here* 12 times to that mixer because the mix was just not quite right. As a producer your only job at the end of the day is ‘can i stand behind this record, is this the best the artist could possibly put out. Does it rule’. THAT is the job of a producer. A guy like Fields might get there by re playing all the instruments when the band leaves. A guy like Rubin might give them a reading assignment. They’re both equally producers because at the end of the day their records are consistently quality, however they get there. THAT is the job. The rest is just details”

The people that know how will always work for the people that know why. 

That lesson was invaluable to me.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
📖 story time:

Arguably one of the most important things I did in my career was a last minute instrumental version of "I Love Rock N Roll" for an A&R at Syco in the US for some random contestant on the short-lived US version of the X Factor. I crushed it on a deadline, then that same A&R hired me a year later to work on a band called Emblem 3 who was on X Factor US as well. I crushed that and then six months after that he recommended me to a UK A&R who was having trouble finishing a song for One Direction. I did a spec production on the song Best Song Ever and they liked it and used it and all of a sudden I become a big pop producer. Stemming from doing an great job on some instrumental cover for a dumb singing tv show.

author: BatMeckley
content:
God I love this discord. 
To me 90% of the reason big producers are paying many thousands a day to be in a studio the past 15-20 years is to just not have to worry about shit. Anyone can make a record at home these days; part of being in an “actual” studio is the cocoon of creativity. If the assistant takes more than a couple of minutes to patch anything in, bring up the piano, or recommend the best Thai place in town, they’re blowing it. I had an assistant once at this place famous for making cookies on site, bring me my normal plate of cookies I always ask for and while I was comping I ate half of one, put it back on the plate, and continued working. He didn’t say a word, got up, grabbed the plate, and disappeared for a few minutes and came back. “Hey man, I know you normally house the entire plate of cookies so when you put that one back I checked with the kitchen and last week I guess they changed the cookie recipe, and they’re gonna make em like they used to for you.” 😂😂. I asked for that dude every session after, less for the cookies but more for the insane attention to detail and telepathy. One of max’s engineers started as a Conway assistant, and as good of an engineer as he was he also prepped the best Hookahs and was just a great hang. Max ended up hiring him for his own studio. We’re in a people business, try to be attentive and a good person to have around, for all the reasons that go beyond knowing how to set an attack on an 1176. 

The flip side is, if you’re booking a studio as a producer, the assistants are what really make the studio run. Treat them well. Know their names. Give them credit. No assistant on any session I ever did paid for their own meal, they got what the artist got.  They most of the time got engineer credits. Help them along. As with all things, mutual respect goes a long way.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Re; Brauer workshop

-First 2 days were nothing technical, the 1st conversation he brought up was about TM and how meditation in general has helped him.
-Everything is feel-based, most technical Q's for the first 2 and a half days got the same reply: "It doesn't matter to me, i don't care what the thing is long as it feels good". 
-MHB actually seems to leave the planet while he's mixing, it's wild how immediate he gets into that space. Seemed to go way past "i love mixing and here's all the reasons i'm the shit" and it was inspiring to see the ego leave the equation. His decades of experience are playing directly into his ability to access the story of the song and present it in a compelling, live-feeling way. He mixes from inside the song and performs. Well, he does discovery, then shapes the sounds, then performs just about everything on faders.
-The biggest wake up call to me is that a lot of moves i've made on mixes did not have a good reason behind them. So continuing to ask "why" as I work is gonna be important, because I have to start catching myself and adjusting when the answer to "why" is "because someone said this preset is cool" or "because this is what I do to a vocal/guitar/drums". I feel music very deeply, it's why i got into this, but I feel like i've been poisoned against trusting that instinct and convinced that what we do is a technical job. I'm done being an observer of the art, i want to be bold.
-It's critical to build trust with clients right away, you can't assume anything in what they understand about how you feel. Telling them you love the song and you're excited to mix it is important, and never blaming production/artist/anything else for the mix being less than what it should be. never okay to say "i did my best", because that gives you an out and implies somebody else could do it better
-Therefore, you must believe when you sit down to mix that nobody is gonna interpret this song better than you.
-Generally i'm skeptical to just take on someone else's "method" and start operating in that space just becuase of the success they've had with it. Putting this week into practice is going to mean using his template to get reps in, listening and feeling and interacting in a new way and letting my brain "level up", if you will, then zooming out and making it my own.


I can distill this more and want to share about a couple other specifics, but I just realized I grabbed someone else's notebook by mistake when I left on the last day so I'll need to have them mail mine back to me.

author: bobby k
content: sort of related, but i've been reflecting a lot on how precious it is to maintain a listener's perspective on a work in progress, and what things we can be doing as the producer/mixer/etc to grant that privilege to the artist first and foremost. the simple stuff includes saving the nitty gritty work for your own time, delivering the best mix of the record no matter the stage it's in, focusing any time spent together on how you can make their voice and contributions and ideas the best they can be. some artists love mixing and editing and getting into the weeds, but i'm realizing quite often how much of a duty it is to be the artist, and how record making is only a single slice of that pie. For us it is more or less the whole pie. and a big responsibility we carry (perhaps without realizing?) is that it is our job to protect the artist from getting  stressed out by the process. and this extends to processing and managing our own stress about the work should it exist, as stress is a contagious energy.

author: BatMeckley
content: But to come full circle, and in line with our talk at Cian’s the other night, my Lol’s on here are more for the 980 people on here that are registered but don’t contribute, or aren’t as active. There are GUARANTEED aspiring engineers, mixers and producers on here that are taking what we say far too seriously, and I feel a genuine responsibility to not entirely dash their dreams because they just spent every dime they had on PMCs or their beats suck. It’s a tricky to path to navigate between taking what we do seriously, without taking ourselves too seriously. It’s a people business, and I do my best to embody on this forum that I’ve found the best way to work consistently in this industry is to be able to take a joke, make a joke, and keep putting out good work. Which I think is FAR more important than if you picked PMCs or ATCs.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Tl;dr- where you are matters as much as who you are. 

I’m also from a small town, moved to LA trying to get famous and got my ass handed to me by artists who were better looking & more talented and yet were still struggling to be seen. But I kept at it because I’m tenacious, (read: delusional, as all artists must be.)

I was able to work *for* some of those artists cause I had a diverse skillset, and I was full time music after about 4 years, by the time I was 26. Doing gigs at hotels and playing guitar or recording for other people, teaching guitar, leading music at churches, all the while pouring evening last ounce of money & energy into my artist career, until my last real artist project broke up the week we were supposed to sign our first record deal. I was 36. 

That’s when I moved to Nashville and really gave myself over to music directing and producing and writing for other artists. I did it as a consolation while I regrouped to find my next thing, but for some reason, when I made the move all the sudden my whole career made sense to me. 

As it turns out, my real joy comes not from the sound of my own voice, but from helping others find theirs. When I acquiesced to that very real, very culturally counterintuitive calling, I thrived. 

All the sudden I was playing music with and for a bunch of my heroes, and all my friends who were artists starting getting famous. And (shocker) I was really glad I wasn’t one of them. 

I always thought that my calling was to help people feel less alone in the world, and that the music I made was the vehicle for that calling. In the end, it turns out it was the relationships i built through music that were the real vehicle.  

It took me a long time to figure out who I was, and the cities I was in played a huge role in that story. Nashville built its whole industry on people who want to *help* artists, not just *be* artists. 

I miss LA every day but I’m in the right place. So, my friend, where is the right place for you?

author: BatMeckley
content:
Sigh… here goes.

Professionally, I legitimately think I’ve learned a new technique or plug in or even way of approaching something EVERY SINGLE DAY im on this discord. The wealth of knowledge on here is staggering, and one of the coolest things about music is you never beat the game; everyday there’s a new technique or something to learn. Personally, I’ve met truly great and meaningful friends through this whole clusterfuck that I will undoubtedly carry with me as I get even older and even greyer. (Like literally, I have to carry Cian around in one of those little baby bjorn things when he gets antsy).

author: popaganda.
content:
You’re gut’s probably right about this situation, but I also feel like you’re saying “everything isn’t the way I want it to be right now so I’m gonna bail.” Collaboration is really hard and nobody gets it 💯 their way, and it sounds like you feel like your efforts are wasted if the aesthetic is fucked. 
But no effort towards making good music is a waste. If that were the case me and a lot of the folks here would be complete losers, but we’re not. We’re actually better for having worked on things that we’d never share willingly.
Is this really a reason to bail? I’m not saying it isn’t. But aesthetics are really subjective. Are you saying your finger’s on the pulse of your generation’s aesthetic taste? Is there room for differences? Also, it sounds like your friend wrote the songs and is the frontman, and you are producing, playing bass, and mixing. Why are you so attached to the visual aspect of it when your role is more support rather than the face of the project?

author: BatMeckley
content:
Full disclosure: I got a bit nervous and uncomfortable last night.

I was having a conversation with my friend Spencer, and he had mentioned that true strength comes from being around a rag tag group of artists and producers of all different levels sharing their knowledge and questions with each other with love and respect, in search of making the best music possible. Hearing him say that gave me a bit of a panic attack; Had I found my weakness? Has that day finally come?

But then I remembered this discord, and all of you lovely, wonderful miscreants, and I realized that’s exactly what I had here. So… nope. Still no weaknesses. Thank you all for the kind words. I’m a lucky dude. Here’s to another year of learning from each other and trying to get better everyday.

author: cian riordan
content:
While the 'science is settled' argument is often used to shut down discussion, it's also rooted in the idea that certain ideas have reached some form of scientific consensus -- usually rooted in findings more exhaustive than off the cuff anecdotal evidence. As somebody with a science background myself, my issue with Jon's claim is that its not rooted in any sort of methodical process. And now kids on the internet get fueled with the idea that one DAW might sound better than another -- instead of focusing on things that make far more of a difference in their productions/mixes/masters/etc.

EDIT: I Have no doubt that if the same person mixed the same song in two different DAWs that they’d come to very different results. But that’s all inherent to the workflow, not to the physics or limitations of that particular DAW.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Growing up in Ireland, without PP I wouldn’t have known that making records could be a legitimate career.

It showcased real life *professionals* working at a high level, and was my introduction to the discourse around the industry. Having only experienced studio work as a cottage industry up to that point, PP opened my eyes to avenues I could pursue that I wouldn’t have known even existed otherwise (recording engineer is different to mixing engineer is different to producer is different to songwriter??!). It all seems very rudimentary now, but I was starting from literally nothing in a place with few (if any?) visible role models.

I learned so much from it on a technical level - from basic stuff like what a Pultec is and how people use it (connecting the dots between my cracked Waves bundle - Puigtec and who tf JJP was), what “a vocal chain” might look like and the purpose of each stage…

True, the interviews did become unbearable, but there was a golden era between eps around 30-90 at a time when outside of working in the studio world, there weren’t many other sources of good information from people who were really doing it.

Huge appreciation for Dave, and I hope he and his family get the support they need.

author: bobby k
content: In the midst of a kinda unique side quest at the moment - label pulls me in at an hourly rate with an artist (and good friend) that I’ve mixed for many times because the production sessions were such a mess that they felt like they couldn’t even finish the records until some light mixing and organization took place. Songs spread out between multiple project files, DAWs, laptops…vocals tracked to mp3s with the ~50ms delay thing…Some of these producers templates…brilliant stuff. Saw one vocal travel through maybe 7 or 8 auxes and hit probably 4 different rvox’s along the way. It was like a labyrinth of signal flow that was nearly impossible to follow (and once I deleted half the auxes and waves plugins, it started to come back to life). In short they’re having me un-mix it, hand it back for some more production, then do the final mixes later this year. A true testament to the importance of organization and more importantly minimalist, straight forward session files. I wonder how often this need comes up and how feasible it is to be involved ahead of the handoff as a mixer these days. And before you frown at me for griping, this is an absolutely incredible project, many insanely talented musicians I respect. Very right brained, free flowing group. So it felt cool to be able to play more of a part on the project as the more left brained participant and see the stress relief happen in real time.

author: Josh
content:
Two years ago I said “no more rock/metal projects” 

Two weeks ago I worked on my first label gig. It was rock/metal. 

Because I’m so far removed from the genre and don’t care for most of the sonics, lyrics, or really anything about the music (generally speaking), I found my ideas stuck out in ways they never did when I was working in the genre. The band valued my input on the deeper production stuff, the lyrics, my melodies and cadences. 

It was my mission to not hate these songs, that was my ONLY goal (pessimistic, but realistic), and I ended up loving every single one of them.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Love the whole conversation above. 

One thing to consider with the whole “people hire me for my taste” thing is that it’s important to have not only a refined palate, but also a broad enough one to be collaborating. 

I’ve worked with extremely talented people who don’t have the breadth to apply their skills to something even slightly outside of their *exact* preference, and I perceive that as being to their detriment. 

If you want to be a professional chef and you make incredible arrabbiata but begrudgingly phone it in with alfredo, you’re going to have a pretty poor career telling Italian restaurants that you’re the right guy for arrabbiata and the wrong guy for alfredo. That’s niching down a little too hard a little too early.

I think it’s our job to find the essence within something and maximally bring that essence out. Often these “taste mismatch” issues come across to me as missing that essence within the thing you’re working on and trying to make it something that it essentially isn’t. ie. A wannabe Max Martin working with a wannabe mitski and the producer complaining that the artist’s suggestions are making the production hashy and the artist complaining that the producer’s production choices don’t convey enough emotion. 

It’s talking past each-other and not really collaborating. You aren’t learning to truly love what your partner loves, which IMO is frankly a big part of the job.

author: cian riordan
content: I’ve spent that last two years almost exclusively mixing and I’m starting to feel a bit bored. For whatever reason, the lane I’ve ended up in (and the skill set I’ve honed) is taking less than ideal recordings and productions, and making them sound professional. I often find myself thinking “if I was recording this, I would have done xyz”. So it’s time to get back into the studio and get things right from the start. Mixing full time is also quite lonely. Pre covid, I was used to being surrounded by interesting, creative people… now most of my interactions are remote. And despite Jon and some other people’s thoughts, I find in person revision sessions to be inefficient and usually unfruitful. So, time to record some stuff.

author: Barbara
content:
Feeling like shite, scheduled an in person mix review, in order to finish this project - communication wasn't being effective, so I though it would be easier this way to get something that would make us both proud.
Got the dry files from the producer 1h before meeting with the band.

The project is finished on my side. On to mastering now. Today feels like the first day of my life 😆

All of this to say what I think is really important and some things I learned that I wish I knew when I was in the middle of those project blues:
1) you WILL get through it.
2) it might be possible to turn it down or pass it to another person
3) trust yourself and your skills to make the best you can
4) set boundaries and expectations. From the start. With the artist and yourself.
5) try to find something you can enjoy during the process - to me, it was on the very last day of mixing that I changed something on my workflow that got me excited, helped me get to the sound of the album we were looking for and will probably be something I will do for every project from now on
6) surround yourself from colleagues/friends who can help you - I know this needs a strike of luck too, but I'm sure if you don't have a reliable in-person "work friend" who can be there for you (with kindness, while keeping it real), this discord might be a good place to ask for that kind of help.

author: cian riordan
content:
The take-way from all this blibber blabber is that I went in expecting to be trusted immediately. I wanted to show off… to establish ‘status’ as Ruairi put it. But it took years of patiently learning the ropes at the highest level to be trusted by the folks in the highest circles. I look back upon that now and I’m still amazed that I was paid to do that. It was essentially like a paid college degree in making records.

So now when I go into studios with a big client, I see the assistant through those eyes. I’m kind but communicative. If they can hang in the back and figure out how I work, anticipate breaks — get the menu book ready — know that we’re going to change gears — start setting up for that — then they get looped in. They get my running commentary on what techniques I’m doing. They get the inside baseball… “I wish they fired this fucking drummer”. 

I agree with Ruairi that this type of coming up through the ranks is a loss for up and comers. It was tried and true way to make people understand the ins and outs of studio technique, etiquette, professionalism. I’m glad I got to ride one of the last waves of it. I wouldn’t be here making records at this level if it weren’t for the opportunities I had at the bottom levels of the industry.

author: LAPhill
content:
To piggyback on @cian riordan 's point, there are real, tangible benefits to being quiet in the back of the room. I would love to be a fly on the wall while @BatMeckley is producing a chart-topping vocalist, or see how Cian works through a first pass of a mix for his next Grammy-winning client. I guarantee they've learned a thing or two about how to talk to sensitive, demanding, highly respected artists. And they've learned how to interpret vague feedback ("make the vocal less green")  and working with people who can't articulate what they want. These are things you can't learn by watching Youtube videos or going to school.

When I was an assistant at Remote Control, getting to sit in and see how Hans handles a note from Jerry Bruckheimer taught me more than years of music education. Watching my boss struggle for 6 months on a 10-minute cue and then sit in a meeting with grace and calm while he's being told to change everything he just spent many long nights working on. 

That's not to mention things like learning how the real pros handle file management, deliveries, deadlines, tech problems, etc.. There is so much beyond learning the gear that comes from being a good assistant. If Matt knows you're going to shut up AND have his back with lackluster cookies, he's going to let you hang in the room longer. Which means you can absorb and learn more. It's a win-win.

author: cian riordan
content: For mix work, I rarely do work-in-progress checks anymore. Although, I'll usually try and listening to mastering returns in Airpods or the car first to get a feel for how it sounds in the real world before geeking out in the studio. When I'm producing & mixing something, I'm often working on it over a longer stretch of time and find real value in listening to something in Airpods while on an airplane or driving around. Given how tuned in we can be as record-makers, I'm always amazed at how valuable passive listening is. I'm usually finding broad stroke adjustments that I can make down the road that really serve the project well.

“Only fools want their own elevator”
This brings to mind a time when I introduced a dude I used to live with to a good friend of mine who had multiple platinum credits, and my friend proceeded to explain his whole process of vocal production to the guy I lived with for a couple of hours straight. Afterwards, my then-roommate said to me “why did he tell me all of that? Now I don’t need him anymore! What an idiot!” And at that moment, I lost all desire to ever work with that dude again.  

Life is largely about family, love, connection, collaboration, etc. without that, what’s the point?

author: popaganda.
content: Several years ago I was on the hunt for the perfect guitar synth and landed on the VG8 from the late 90s. It was a weird box but had some amazingly responsive presets in it, nestled between random shred tones. It was awesome but I never made much music on it, and it ended up in my closet bc it was too bulky to live on my studio floor. I have to admit I felt jealous when this mk.gee wave hit and I saw 2 vg8s on the stage. I was sitting on a goldmine but I didn’t use it enough and they got there first! Been playing baritones for a long time too, fingerstyle. The lesson for me in this is that no matter what sounds are available to me, I need to be constantly re-connecting to my Why. Why do I make music? Remembering with a sense of urgency my need to express the deepest parts of myself and not just getting tossed around in a land of “shoulds,” chasing fads, second-guessing authentic ideas.

author: BatMeckley

This is what I meant to say.
You’re probably not going to get a particularly serious or even accurate answer from most people to the “what’s great about you” question”. Best to ask trusted colleagues or third parties. 

For instance, having worked with Noah, his strengths as a producer outside of his obvious musical talent is his attitude with the artist. He’s, patient, kind, and authentically curious about what makes the other person great. A lot of people with his talent and odometer would go “do it like THIS”. Fun to watch, and everyone leaves the session feeling better about themselves and the song.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok gang, here’s something I’ve been pondering

Imagine 3 sliders that go from 0 to 10. Your goal is to set the sliders to maximize your wellbeing (in the broadest sense) and the wellbeing of those close to  you. The sliders are in effect zero sum, in that the closer you are to one end then less you have of the attribute on the other end. Let’s set the time horizon to 25 years and acknowledge the seemingly increasing pace of change in the world

Ok, the sliders …

**#1 Classics vs Cutting Edge**
On this slider 0 represents maximum knowledge in a classical sense - literature, math, mythology, fundamental accepted basics in Biology/Chemistry/Physics etc etc. 10 represents complete literacy in the cutting edge of culture, science and technology - from memes and Reddit culture to AI to synthetic biology and Blockchain etc etc 

**#2 Specialist vs Generalist**
Here 0 represents a very deep and specific knowledge of a chosen field (could be a doctor or a producer) vs 10 representing a modern Jack of all trades who knows a little bit about a lot of things 

**#3 Short Term vs Long Term**
On the slider 0 represents a disposition all about short term wins, fast plays that close out over a year vs 10 representing long investments in a given idea/field/belief system

It goes without saying that the zero sum aspect here is artificial, you can of course have some long term plays happening alongside some short term, but it’s just to get the juices flowing

author: NoahNeedleman

I respect this take, but I disagree. 

Amending roles ex post facto is a shitty move, but fighting for the byline when no one looks up credits anyway… there’s just no upside. 

I just did “additional production” on a track that will be credited as “guitars,” because that’s what it took to get the song over the finish line. Now the song is gonna be a single that’s going to radio for the artist.

author: cian riordan
content: Eventually I caught the hang of things. I started to study the rhythms of the sessions, what order people would file in every morning. I knew the singer liked coffee one way, another guy did something else… I’d start to have that stuff ready. Instead of chumming it up with the band trying to fend off boredom while Eric was mid task, I stuck around on the couch… watching patiently. Those were the moments where he would start looping me into what he was doing, explaining his techniques. Before I knew it, I could start anticipating what he would need next. Someone mentions trying some vocals on a thing? I immediately got going on setting up a mic, getting headphones, even starting to dial in a mix on the headphone box. Percussion? Grab the trunk of junk and start laying out potential options. Once I started actually being useful, I’d be given real tasks. “Hey, do you think you could try doing a preliminary comp of this vocal?” I had been in the room for all the vocal takes, heard the discussion about approach and vibe, even made the singers coffee the right way… why not? That evolved into being trusted with recording stuff in the second studio… we were always running behind, and having me chip away at guitar tracking or re-amping was really useful. Years of this and we were a well oiled machine. I’d get looped into pre-production phone calls and meetings, he would start asking my opinion on things.. drum sounds, microphone choices.

author: LAPhill
content:
I don't know why I didn't think of this sooner, but the closest parallel to the seismic shift of AI might be samples, even more so than things like digital recording or Pro Tools. When Hans Zimmer recorded an orchestra and started writing music with a DAW and showing clients mockups, nothing was ever the same. For a long time (even now!) the pencil-and-paper people griped about how it wasn't real composition. Orchestras feared that they would all be replaced by computers. But ultimately, everyone had to come to terms with the new world order and adapt. There was a period in the mid-90s through mid-late 2000s where orchestral writing was reduced to nothing more than long notes and short notes. All of the nuance was gone, because the tech couldn't handle it yet and people blamed the tech. Many mourned the loss of true orchestral writing, yearning for a by-gone era. 

But eventually, people learned to harness these new tools and they met the technology on its own terms. People are doing wildly innovative things with samples now, we've moved completely past the era of "can I make a convincing clarinet come out of my keyboard?" Orchestras and live musicians have not been replaced. Sure, the process is different than it used to be, but that's how innovations work. All of us would be living very different lives without samples of drums, guitars, orchestras, synths, etc. There will be a generation coming up where AI is already a thing, they won't have ever lived in the before-times. Just like those here who've never cut to tape. It's okay.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Got a call this week to save a track. Producer turned it in pretty half baked and didnt give the mixer any direction. The first time the artist heard it was first pass at mix, and he HATED it. 

Artist was SUPER uncomfortable about the whole thing, but didn’t trust the producer to get it done for a bunch of reasons. 

1) the producer rushed the vocal recording. Artists wanted more takes but basically got bullied out of the room. 
2) The artist wanted to be there for the comp at least, producer refused. As I said, first time he heard it was after first mix pass. 
3) producer baked some Sonics into the vocal that were very outside for the artist, and there were bad edits & poor Melodyne work to boot. 


Now not only is the mixer gonna have to mix the vocals all over again (we’re retracking,) but all the other shit I’m adding/changing. 

So this producer made the artist uncomfortable and then made more work for everyone, on a major label budget. 

I’m not gonna speculate on the why, but there are some lessons here.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Awesome. I'm seeing this right now with a friend's band, so ima jump on the bandwagon here. I just took over mixing the album, which has been in progress for years. Everybody tells me the producer/band leader is this prolific asshole, constantly blowing up at people and impossible to please. The previous mixer had been mixing this thing for months/over a year and everyone was worn out/not getting results. I was really reluctant to take on the project for fear of being intimidated/failing to deliver.

I've made a point of greeting the producer at every step with clear communication, enthusiasm, and an open mind. I genuinely love the music and have made a point of letting him know how much fun it's been to work on the stuff. And, similar to your story, we were basically approved on the first track within 4 mixes and the guy seemed really really happy.

Everyone just said this guy was a hopeless asshole, but what I saw was a guy who was working so hard to bring a vision to life and just struggling to get there; self-financing, overseeing everything, etc... and it's fairly complex, hip hop and soul vibes with practically a full orchestra and 3 vocalists, so it's a lot to manage. Not trying to excuse the asshole behavior, but I see the frustration and I really wanted to highlight how much cool work he had done and that, without any fuss or needless back and forth, we would just get it where it needed to go. i tried to just think about how exciting it could be to finally hear these songs that've been bouncing around in his head actually come out of the speaker the way he imagined. We've got 7 songs almost done now and I've grown so much just from these attitude alignments i've picked up from spending time here.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Another quick story, I was streaming a production/mix with my old boss / mentor / producer Jon Kaplan, thinking I was close and just wanting an outside ear. 

During the first chorus, Kaplan goes “solo the kit… flip the phase on the mono room and dip 400hz in that mic.”

He didn’t even ask if there *was* a mono room mic. 

And I kid you not, all the sudden the snare jumped like 4db in the mix. I muted the claps I was using to bolster 2 & 4 and the mix was done. 

That was one of the most virtuousic moments of listening I’ve ever witnesssed.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I'm totally with you on all this.

The question for me is less about the credit/ title, and more about the role. How do you get perspective at the end of the record making process? This role is changing, and we'd all be smart to understand where it's headed.

I get hired to finish songs a lot. Usually that means I have a "co-producer" credit. Sometimes it means "mixer" credit. Occasionally it's included "mastering." But really what I'm hired for is that combination of experience and technical knowledge. I'm an outside ear who knows how to fix what's missing. This role of "finisher" is really where a lot of the producer/ mixer/ mastering engineer profession is headed. The distinction between those roles is getting blurrier. 

Mixing engineers have moved from pulling up faders on the console and creating a mix (old school "mixers") to often just pulling up the rough mix of stems and making finishing touches (Jon, Manny, Serban, Tony, Bainz, etc.).

In this way, the "mixing engineer" profession is moving away from manipulating raw sounds to manipulating nearly finished mixes. This is sounding more and more like what a "mastering engineer" does. Now there's "stem mixing" and "stem mastering" too, further blurring the lines. These are all just slightly different configurations of the same thing. Who do you hire to get perspective and then act on it?

Those of us that are finishers or mixers or mastering engineers or whatever would be smart to think about how to adapt to the direction this is all headed. 

I want us all to win. I think we need to step back and expand how we think about the roles. It's the best way for us all to have careers.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
not a weird question at all. something that took me a long time be comfortable with. i now say "i'm a record producer and songwriter." if people have follow ups or have decent knowledge, ill get into more specifics and clarify.

it's always a little awkward when someone follows up with things like "what genre?" or "anything i would know?" but you just figure out how to slowly let out more information if people are interested. 

"i produce music" is usually a pretty good response, even if you're more of a mixer or engineer or whatever.

i always try and remember that most everyone is interested because making music has a cool cache, but they always feel like an idiot for not knowing how it works. they often feel more uncomfortable than you do. treat your response as a thing to make them feel good.

author: BatMeckley
content: In all of this, as you pursue your passion, I’d say remember that what you’re great at might not be what you thought you’d be great at, or even what you’re working towards. I doubt Ruairi was a 12 year old dreaming of being the hot shit mastering engineer. I CERTAINLY didnt think I’d be a vocal producer, that gig didn’t even exist when I was a kid. The great music lawyer Donald Passman writes about how he got the “maybe the ‘music’ bit of ‘music business’ isn’t where your specific skill set resides” conversation and it changed his life for the better. Keep your head up while running down the court, you might see open lanes you weren’t expecting.

author: cian riordan
content:
In the studio, this was like getting a golden ticket. It turns out, there’s no shortcut to greatness. You have to put in the work. Want to get a great drum sound? Do the work. Pick out the right drums. Spend time tuning them. Put them in the right place in the room. Try different places in the room. Try different drums. Setup some microphones. Listen. Adjust. Move the microphones. Maybe change the drums. Maybe change the microphones. Maybe they don't sound good because the part isn’t right? Maybe it's something else in the arrangement? Take it out. Try it. 

This takes quite a bit of motivation to get this deep in the weeds. But the results? Well, they were always unquestionably great. Could it have been fine with less work? Maybe. But you’d never know. And nobody is going to care about this record more than you are.

author: Deleted User
content:
My humble opinion on this from a producer POV is that if the vision was compelling to me in the beginning from a foundational level, then it’s not done until everyone in the team feel good; and that includes myself. I always push to the point of it feeling as good as I can get it, then present it to the artist. I’d give them about a week or two to sit with it if they need to, if they love it then its a go- if they don’t and feel that what I did got in the way of their vision, I scrap it. 

If I took on the project and wasn’t fully on board with the vision, then I don’t go as far as I would normally go- but I still try to push it as far as possible and then let the artist decide

Rick Rubin’s A-B-C theory - If artist want’s A and you want B, then you need to find C that does both A and B. It’s not done yet

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Not sure how long you feel like you've been in this state, but it kinda sounds like you're describing the place just before it's your lyrics and arrangements on NMF. 

It's hard to draw parallels because I came up pre streaming and there's just a lot more people making records. But I had my first 3-4 things that started getting attention get taken away from me by managers/ labels/ bigger producers/ bigger mixers. Once I got to that next level it was obvious why I wasn't the guy yet. But if you're working on things that are at some point getting out there in a real way, that's the place that most people are before they jump up. 

Some of it is opportunity, some of it is skillset, some of it is time management (if you're hustling, it helps to turn great shit around before everyone else), and some of it is just the intangibles that come from more reps. 

My One Direction song came out 17 years after I first recorded the first band I was in. I'm not recommending anyone spend 17 years doing something all the time for no real money. But that's how it went for me.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’m with Beckley on this. I get hired because of my taste, and I go into projects with full communication re: what is intended. 

I don’t say “this sucks I’m gonna fix it.” I say “I have some ideas about how to pull this into a really kickass place.” 

Very rarely as a mixer am I *only* mixing. Bass comes in and has no booty? Chances are I’m gonna be doing more than bx-subsynth to make it thump. Only tracked one guitar and it’s supposed to be huge? I’m gonna add some to really make that sell. 

I don’t always assume I know more than the artist, but the truth is, with the level of artists I usually work with, MOST of the time I do. 

That’s not an ego trip, it’s an understanding of the gig. It’s why people hire me. Why they ask for my help. And I treat that with deep respect. 

Last night Rauirí basically bullied me into buying RX standard for a project I was doing as a favor to a friend. I SPENT MONEY to do this thing. Because as Rauirí says: “Art matters.” 

And as Beckley ranted yesterday, I don’t think we should let something suck because we were only hired for a job. We’re not house painters who decided to fix a furnace. We’re general contractors who know how a house is built, and we fix shit that’s broken. (Bad example, but you get it.)

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s tricky, it’s a bit how I was saying the old head front of house guy was probably underselling his knowledge. 

There is a friend of mine that’s
worked on some massive records, and they did a bunch of interviews and tik toks about all of the work and automation and plugins and processing that it took to make the record sound great, and while they work a ton, it always struck me that if I was the artist I would be hesitant to work with such a “look how responsible _I_ am for the end product” producer. 

I’ve always tried to come from the perspective of whenever I’m asked about a record I’ve worked on with “man, the artist just sounds like that in the room, I was just lucky to be there and try and capture the magic” 

It’s not an apples to apples comparison with Rubin, but benefit of the doubt style MAYBE there’s a bit of that in there? I’ve always thought the kids just want to believe the person on the poster is the genius. They don’t need to know an 40 yo married couple wrote Sk8r Boi.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pretty damn frequently. Producers moreso than mixers.

When I find a record that resonates with me I'm very full-immersion and I'll devour as much of their adjacent body of work as I can. I'll start scrutinizing the record credits and pulling on threads as I see them. I really try to fill in the context around the record by identifying all collaborators, timelines, interviews they gave around that time, published works, etc. I've got a huge appetite for that thing.

I really love reading books written by producers. The more old school the better. Phil Ramone's *Making Records* is a great one. That guy is a class act. Quincy Jones has both an autobiography *and* a book specifically on producing. The latter is a great no-shortcuts look at what it takes to be great. I enjoyed Daniel Lanois' *Soul Mining*, since he's got a very thoughtful immersive way of making records and working with artists that I appreciate.

author: peterlabberton
content: Just offering this as another perspective, but one that's more focused on engineering, not producing: I worked on *so* many lame ass records and projects that I'd never show anyone, but I saw every one as an opportunity to build my engineering chops on someone else's dime. This was mainly as a staff engineer at a big studio, which is its own hustle, but if you can look for something to learn/improve/gain on each project, I don't think every single session needs to be the most artistically/personally satisfying thing. Then you have this wealth of experience to take into the sessions that do really matter. You're sharpening your tools everyday if you can land a situation like that—AND if it's aligned with what you ultimately want to do.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
For real. Yesterday had an almost hallucinogenic texture to it - like, I’d spent time with all of the elements of this production, and I felt like I’d seen them from all angles. In a way I had - from all of the exterior angles that were visible to me.

But when my pal jumped on and started working with the drum mics (a lot of Decap and Saturn in split band - drawing all sorts of wild life, depth and dimension out of an innocuous extra snare mic).

It was as if he’d stuck his fingers through the shell of a watermelon and pulled it wide open, red stuff and pips flying everywhere. All I’d thought to do was rotate the melon on different axes and shine lights on it to get different shades of green. It never occurred to me to pull the insides out and splatter everything red.

author: joshbonanno
content: i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face....wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great, because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist...or in some cases, even the intended audience. with that said...if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. / might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it...so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world...but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Also think about turnaround times. You work on 15+ songs a day as an ME, you hear aberrant clicks and pops in *nearly every single one of them* 

With asking the person who sent you the files to do it, you spend your whole day emailing and managing files. It takes longer to open gmail than it does to zap the click. 

And think of the logical conclusion of asking the mixing engineer to fix the edit. They don’t have the edit, they have the comp. So then if you extend the logic they have to hit up the producer, and MAYBE the producer has to hit up the recording engineer if you really wanna “get to the source”. It’s like the meme of the producer who didn’t want to use splice because it was cheating and ended up farming sheep to get skin to make his own drumheads. Just do the fucking work. There’s no time to email back and forth about things that can be fixed immediately

author: cian riordan
content:
Simple answer, but probably the greatest thing I ever learned from EV is: "it's all about how much you care”. 

If any of you have spent time around him or seen his videos, it’s pretty clear that he goes deep on all of his productions… there’s no stone that’s left unturned, no excuse to not take it fully to the end zone. There were surely some parts of this that seemed exhausting during the record making process… it surely broke a lot of musicians sitting bored on the control room couch for weeks on weeks on weeks while he labored over their recordings.

author: Slow Hand
content:
After a decade of performing, touring, and doing production work (and stressing about financial insecurity through much of it) I started an unrelated business with a partner four years ago.

This has turned out to be the right choice for me because it relieves the financial stresses and insecurities and (much like @kidcutler) it allows me to cherry pick the gigs that I want to do.

For a while, making a living on music was a point of pride (or shame when it was not going well). I've always felt a tension between the work that I wanted to create and it's commercial viability. So finding an alternate path to support myself has taken a huge cognitive load off of me and given me the independence to relax and (consequently) better fund my music ventures and enjoy the process again.

author: cian riordan
content: Sonic consistency amongst songs on a record is one of those things that gets harder as you move further through the production processes. In an ideal world, you'd map out an aesthetic for a record in pre-production and make choices in recording & production to try and stay within those lines, whatever that means. A real world example I have is when I was doing the last Mini Mansions album, we locked onto a few H3000 patches that sort of defined how the drums and ambience would sound throughout the record. We obviously didn't use it on everything, but it helped thread the needle through a wildly diverse batch of songs. After that, having one person mix the whole album will undoubtedly help tie together a record that's been all over the map in production -- be it different styles or producers. As someone that often is tasked with doing this, I am always referencing other songs in the album to try and make sure things are sounding 'consistent'. By the time mastering comes, everything should sound 99% complete.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Stereo. I tried out some Atmos headphone mixes at an Apple store kiosk a while ago because I was curious. I can't say that it had much of an effect on me. Maybe I need to live with them for longer and get used to it.

Last week was the first time that I was able to sit in front of an Atmos setup that was meant for music (aka: not in a movie theater) and really get the full musical experience. In fact, I got to sit in front of *three* different Atmos rigs in three different (treated) rooms that evening and two of them were undoubtedly set up as good as they could have possibly been (One was a PMC showroom and the other built and tuned with their input). While the speakers themselves were impressive and very capable, the actual experience felt pretty disjointed. There was a pronounced feeling of phasi-ness that I didn't like.

It was great hearing these records on a rig that probably cost $250k, but my big takeaway was that they felt disjointed and odd. Even when sitting in the sweet spot.

Perhaps my opinion will change with more exposure, but I'm not yet convinced that it's worth the time and effort. I will add, though, that half the mixes we heard were up-mixed from old stereo recordings with minimal track counts and only two of them were modern productions.

author: Barbara
content:
I have to let you know my first experience with this. Been working on an album that I recorded one year ago. Recording took us 7 days and they still needed to add synths and bass fot some of the songs after that (side note: the production wasn't finished by the time we tracked, so I edited everything I had - 10 songs, none of them with less than 5 minutes. It was the band's first time in the studio, also, and had to edit lots of drums and bass stuff). After doing a first pass, I sent them the multitracks they asked for, to track the rest of their stuff with their producer (a colleague of mine). The next 8 months were spent waiting on their files to start mixing (this was supposed to last 1/2 months, max). When I finally got the files, you have no ideia how messy the project turned out (track names, bounce mistakes, ultrapocessed tracks with artifacts - even the ones we've tracked at the studio before, audible edit points,... all you can imagine going wrong at this point), so it took me a bunch of time to organize everything in a way that I could work with what I've got (going back and forth asking the producer for some files that didn't even get to me or asking if there was the possibility to get some of the tracks dry, without processing or fx - keep this in mind).

Needless to say, when I was ready to start mixing, I was already overwhelmed and tired of it, and I knew I still had a long way to go...

First version took me probably too long to get right (2 months, approx., working on other projects that got scheduled on those 8 months) and I've sent it before I went on a few days vacation.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Schedule, schedule, schedule. I use a productivity app called Notion. Make multiple bottles ahead of time. That way you don’t have to stop working to make a bottle. You can pull them out of the refrigerator whenever you need, warm em up and you’re good to go. Most formula last at least 24 hours in the refrigerator. Breast milk is easier to work with because you can freeze it, grab it, and thaw it when you’re ready to use it. Plan your breaks around feeding. When he’s playing or napping, you can work. Make sure he’s visible tho. Have a bassinet, bouncer, or something next to your chair. Open backs help when mixing because you can hear if he cries. Babies love white noise. Play that shit on loop while he sleeps and he’ll be out for hours at a time. Use brown switches for your keyboard if you can get them. Those are extremely quiet and won’t wake the baby. 

That’s off of the top of my head. I might think of something else and add it here. CONGRATULATIONS!!!

author: BatMeckley
content:
Years ago, a buddy of mine was DESPERATE for John Field’s snare sample. And i tried to explain to him it was more about arrangement and how the instruments around the snare work. And he was like “yeah I GET IT, but can I have the snare”. And this was a guy with good ears that plays guitar for STADIUMS.

So I say of course, come on by and I’ll give you the sample. And he without prompting goes “I’ll give you all my samples for that one”. I assure him that’s unnecessary but he insists. He comes by my place, plugs his drive in, and the very first sample he gives me is the John Fields snare sample.

I can’t help but think people are chasing proficiency in the wrong areas.

author: spectrummasters
content: Hi, yes so......within the genres I’m most involved in currently hip/hop , drill and rnb the samples we choose and the patterns we create for these samples are all “trendy “ in a sense that it’s important in our genres to be seeking to present new sounds and patterns that others catch onto . This would be being the new wave . It’s vital in uk street music to be a creator of the wave / up on the new wave .....to garner attention . This dates back to jungle....where the producer/engineers were pioneering completely new sounds and rhythms via sampler technology midi and sampled breakbeats (amen , funky drummer etc ) . When a snare backbeat transitions from the use of a snare to instead a rimshot......or a particular clap sample.....and that track blows up, the wave moves . If you a year later release a track with the old snare on the backbeat instead of the rim .....that’s dated . The same goes for the other percussions, the bass sounds (eg 808 / Moog in intro/bridge combi ) .....and the patterns . So this is why In twelve months most of the productions these artists are dithering over , will be out of date. It’s just silly imo. Music is moving so fast and is ultimately so disposable at the mo holding onto it like some sort of special Tolkien esque ring is really just a vanity. Personally I’d venture this is also the essence of what makes pop music trends discernible . That’s just my opinion tho with respect to these genres. My overall goal is to record and mix work like rumours. Smokey , earthy and nourishing . A bit like @popaganda.  s last work .🙏🏼

content:
Bear in mind also that the references are UK specific, and this is a work in progress.


- A Minimum Rate Card (a reference for minimum per-hour and per-day rates, according to role and project budget, with additional minimum fees for equipment rental). As an example, see the current BECTU Production Sound rate card https://members.bectu.org.uk/filegrab/bectu-production-sound-rates-nov-2021-final.pdf?ref=2606

- Standardised working hours and breaks

- Minimum time off between working days, with breaches (“overnight infringement”) incurring additional fees for freelancers, or days-off in lieu for contracted workers

- Guaranteed minimum rates of overtime pay

- Special rates of pay for bank holidays

- An enforced system to credit all workers for their contributions – runners, assistants, ops, and engineers (think the credits at the end of a movie)

- Special rates of pay for weekends [Sunday bonus rates (but not Saturdays) are common in theatre. Some other industries pay weekends at time-and-a-half]

- Special rates of pay for planned overnight sessions [This is also common in theatre, film and tv, enforced by BECTU in those instances]

author: BatMeckley
content:
Lots actually. My family was in aerospace (my stepdad manufactured rivets for airplanes) and then had a safety distribution company. They retired and went into VC and real estate.

I remember sitting down and trying to explain to Bill Gross (whose son I was managing and producing) how the record deal we were just about to sign with Sony worked and he was like “what the fuck?!” 😂😂😂 Took him a while to believe that the music business actually “worked” that way.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s just an entirely different product, and entirely different type of people on the spectrum that make it.

I don’t want to assume too much about any particular software business but I assume you’re building software to solve a problem. There’s a right and a wrong way to do it, and a price to come in at. (These rivets will hold up under this amount of stress up against this material so your plane doesn’t fall out of the sky). With music and production, the goal is a lot more amorphous, especially outside of pure radio pop production (I’ve already beaten that horse dead here.) The concepts of done and value are much harder to define because it’s in the eye of the beholder. 

Then, there’s the specific people. Most people that are in software or data management didn’t grow up going “I WANNA BE IN DATA MANAGEMENT”. They fell in to the field because they had an aptitude for it, were good at numbers, and it was a good way to make money so they can pursue their passion outside their job. With musicians, they specifically ran from that kind of life, the music IS the passion. A guy like cian or Noah could make a factor of 10 time more money in another field, but the emotional value they get from their work supersedes that.

It’s just chalk and cheese.

author: BatMeckley

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
I’ve referenced this more than once in conversations here and in DMs with various people but it is remarkably applicable to what we do too if you can open up the aperture a little 

Musk’s Engineering Philosophy:

Musk overviewed his five step engineering process, which must be completed in order:

**1) Make the requirements less dumb.** The requirements are definitely dumb; it does not matter who gave them to you. He notes that it’s particularly dangerous if an intelligent person gives you the requirements, as you may not question the requirements enough. “Everyone’s wrong. No matter who you are, everyone is wrong some of the time.” He further notes that “all designs are wrong, it’s just a matter of how wrong.”

**2) Try very hard to delete the part or process.** If parts are not being added back into the design at least 10% of the time, not enough parts are being deleted. Musk noted that the bias tends to be very strongly toward “let’s add this part or process step in case we need it.” Additionally, each required part and process must come from a name, not a department, as a department cannot be asked why a requirement exists, but a person can.

**3) Simplify and optimize the design.** This is step three as the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize something that should not exist.

**4) Accelerate cycle time.** Musk states “you’re moving too slowly, go faster! But don’t go faster until you’ve worked on the other three things first.”

**5) Automate.** An important part of this is to remove in-process testing after the problems have been diagnosed; if a product is reaching the end of a production line with a high acceptance rate, there is no need for in-process testing.

author: franc.castillejos
content:
That really resonates. Geography has been the biggest question for me too—it’s shaped so much of my journey, and it still feels like the missing piece I need to figure out.

I spent over a decade playing in bands in the states back when I had a student visa , chasing the idea that making my own music was the only way to carve out a place in this world. But like you, I eventually realized that what I really love is helping others find their sound—producing, mixing, bringing songs to life in ways that feel true to the artist. That shift was huge for me, but the where of it is now  the open question.

Your story is a reminder that the right place isn’t just where opportunity exists—it’s where our purpose makes the most sense. I’m grateful you shared it. Now I just need to find my Nashville.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When I'm producing and writing, I try and think of it much more binary:

If I'm creating, I am trying to avoid giving myself any options. Options force me to make conscious decisions. Conscious decision making is antithetical to making good art. I'm going for feeling and execution. 

If I'm refining/ finishing, or I am setting up the larger workflow, I allow myself all the rabbit holes and options I need. I make different versions and analyze. I zoom way in and then zoom way out and then zoom way in again. At some point I stop, but that's variable based on schedule, budget, sleep deprivation, interpersonal obligations, etc.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is an issue that the artist and producer should be resolving amongst themselves. It's not yours to mediate.

By telling you to exclude the producer the artist is externalizing the problem to you and pulling you into the disagreement between them.

By sidebar-ing with the producer (as was suggested elsewhere) you're expanding the complexity of the communications between all three parties. Now you're the go-between for everyone. That's messy.

Moreso than that, talking to the producer on the side and updating them on what's going on may feel like a betrayal by you from the artist's perspective, because they clearly don't want the producer to know.

I would seek to steer them both towards some version of "I can't be the one to solve this for either of you, and you need to resolve it amongst yourselves."

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Yo speaking on what @Nomograph Mastering said a few days about staying cool…we have a producer in and so the whole room is a giant mess (like most studios are when they are locked out) and we sold an amp and we wanted to make profiles/name of it before it went out the door 

So the patchbay is a huge mess and I hooked up all the routing and wasn’t getting signal and I started to lose my cool and got super frustrated, Rick calmed me down and we worked out what problem was (I forgot I was feeding the the amp from the di multed on the patchbay instead of feeding it from the converter to run tones..) and after I got cooled down it clicked on why I wasnmt getting signal.



It’s extremely difficult to not get frustrated when trouble shooting and not get overwhelmed by a full patchbay but if you just take a second and breathe/calm down and start reversing your signal flow you’ll find the culprit and move on




Long story short as an engineer you gotta be the calmest one in the room

author: cian riordan
content: Nail on the head. I think I had mentioned this in a previous post, but these days notes tend to come in real time -- via text messages, dropbox comments, or sometimes even thoughtful emails. I'll usually take a quick glance, but then dump everything into a note file so I have everything in one place when I sit to do the revision. This can be useful when you'll get a thread of notes like 1) I'm not sure about the drum sound, it feel so x... then 2) someone else will chime in saying I love the drums! I think x is the problem then 3) first person is hesitant and shrugs of their not, even though it may still bother them. That way I can try and string together some sort of move that will hopefully make everyone happy. If you're dealing with a band -- and you're producing/engineering -- you'll have had the benefit of seeing the dynamic. Sometimes you get some people that are more engaged and tweaky, others that are unsure of EVERYTHING, and then people that when they say something, they're usually right, as infrequent as that may be. This is very useful during mix notes time because you have context. If you're just getting flies flown to you and you've never met the band/artist, thats certainly a bit more of a challenge and will likely require more work on your end to smooth things out.

author: Deleted User
content: recognizing if my reaction is coming from my taste or objective observation is another thing that guides me when I give feedback to others. I do mention my personal reactions but I try to be clear that it is my personal reaction not a real observation. But it’s very difficult, I’ve read from a book “nonviolent communication” once that the highest form of intelligence is making observations without making judgements. And I confuse these things often too. So I think it is a skill that can be applied to providing feedback. I also find it helpful to offer choices as feedback. For example, if (intention) is what you are going for trying (suggestion) may work well. But if (a different angle) is what you are going for, (a different suggestion) can be another thing you can try. This, I do more often as a producer. As casual feedback, I don’t do this very often other than people I am close to.

author: alecdibell2
content:
@absflores The bounces I send to clients are always labelled “in.prog” until we decide on the final mix.  It keeps things organized if they liked something about “in.prog1”, that we moved away from, and wanted to bring back in “in.prog3”.

I don’t send an in.prog until I feel just about done with the mix, or I want to ask the artist about their intention on a specific part of the track, before moving through that section of the mix. It’s mostly an organizational tool for me, and keeps the artist in the loop with the process being a collaboration

author: jonmatteson
content:
I do a lot of MD/live show building work and would advise against using a set up like this for a few reasons:
1. Having computers on stage is always risky especially when you don’t NEED it
2. There are better solutions for live guitar without using a $2000 computer. I use HX Stomps or helix on most gigs as well as kempers. These allow for midi changeable patches from playback as well as zero latency performance. Also they sound pretty great and have everything you could need in them!
3. If you use one of the above units you can back them up to your computer or thumb drive and in the event that one bites the dust, you can go buy one at your local guitar center and play the show instead of having to buy a new computer, authorize plugs, etc. 
Just my two cents!

author: frankieharper
content:
Thought for the end of the day… UK time 

Our arrangements and our mixes leap into existence from the womb of the metaphysical into a world rich in strict guidelines and predetermined boundaries. It’s drill, it NEEDS that thump… it’s lofi, it neeeeeds that blur, I want to get onto New Music Friday, it needs to be LoUd. 

Genre and playlists seem to rule with an iron fist… I often think that when an artist asks for a ‘brighter’ mix or an even MORE colossal 808. Not always… but often. 

Surely the overall and final sonic characteristic of our various musical expressions should be treated with as much emotional sensibility as our lyric or our narrative? 

Perhaps a dark lyric cries out for a dark mix… New Music Friday or otherwise?

Or is that built in?
 *wild generalisation hat firmly secured* 
Would it be too much of a reach to say that modern pop music is bright and loud because in recent history, pop music is high energy and bright in tone? Or is jazz historically observed from the back of a smoky leather bound room and so dark and dynamic just sits comfortably (whisky in hand) … I guess my question is… at risk of sounding a little Orwellian, do we control genre or does genre control us? Probably both? Asking for a friend.

author: spectrummasters
content: @bobby k So way waaaaay back in the uk , when drum and bass and dubstep (and garage ) didn’t exist yet there were a few london based producers scattered about manipulating breakbeats like james browns funky drummer drum break , the amen drum break from the Winston brothers and the apache drum break . England had had breakbeat hardcore for a few years already (eg . Early early prodigy ) and then the British carribean community and others familiar with reggae and particularly the early 90s ragga scene in Jamaica , started fusing ragga acapellas and dub bass line motifs with hardcore ‘s drum breaks . This was pioneering and was referred to as future sounds  , back then the mode was established for U.K. street music producers to value “futuristic “ aka pioneering / unheard of / new sounds and rhythms .

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Love this discussion. All great points — my gut says there is a distinction between the producer/engineer role here and the artist. The learn grammar, be able to adjust and deliver on a vision/etc all lend themselves to being amazing technically and doing the reps to have those skills. Very useful on the service side

But some artists just have it like that. It’s irrelevant, they just crush stuff and have a vision. Pure talent. And probably the rarest ones have both sides and are aware of it. Then you’re truly dangerous

Have seen this with some football guys I’ve played with — I was one of the ones who studied the game deeply and could improve. But other guys showed up on day one, knew absolutely nothing but could just ball. Their knowledge of the game didn’t even matter, they could just ball on instinct. Of course they worked hard, but there was a different level of talent there. And look at them now, cashing checks in the NFL

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Folks, anyone willing to jam on this? I'd welcome some perspective and am curious what others might think:

At times as a producer I feel that I have needed to become the 'artist by proxy'. At times as a mixer I feel I have needed to become the 'producer by proxy'. As well I could imagine how a mastering eng might feel they need become the 'mixer by proxy'. This language arises for me the more aware I am of what a 'great vision for a song', 'great production', 'great mix' *could* be and what it actually is in front of me. As well as from preconceptions of what the record making roles are about. I'm trying to connect the idea of a producer being someone who uncovers or brings forth an artist's vision (i.e. *"I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free" - Michelangelo*) and someone who sometimes needs to manifest the vision when it is lacking.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Full disclosure, I don’t think PG got a lot of writing done that day.

But “the whole point of being a record producer is to at the end of the day actually produce a record, like, have a recording that you can show for it” feels like a reasonable hill that I’m comfortable dying on. Sometimes that’s just impossible to achieve despite our best efforts. But I feel like the best effort part is important. Otherwise, it feels like watching a bunch of westerns on tv and wearing a cowboy hat and going “im a cowboy”. Which is a totally fun goal (go to desert 5 spot in Hollywood), but I don’t think qualifies as an actual cowboy.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content: Productivity is awesome. It can even be awesome when work consumes someone's life, to an extent. author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Yeah for sure! Sounds like you're on a good path!! Totally understand the hesitation to delegate - especially that first 6 months-a year where you're acutely aware that helping someone else do it is *more work* than just rolling up your sleeves and doing it yourself. 

For building systems, what's worked for me is hiring and training your 'double(s)' first - someone with a similar skillset and sensibilities, very broad skills like me (who also did everything myself for a long time). This comes a lot easier if you have close friends in the same lane looking for jobs, I've seen people have their "double(s)" move in with them for a limited time too, with the intention of them soaking in exactly all you do.

Once my double(s) started doing pretty well, we started hiring more specialized people, and the doubles could then oversee their work, feedback etc - early on I would always be part of this, then slowly phase myself out.

What I wish I would have done earlier would have been to hire a producer/overseer/manager/'my boss' - someone with a bit more skin in the game/responsibility, and who keeps you in line if you start wavering. 

Again, I didn't love the setup of 10 and dissolved it eventually - as a creative it's easy to feel like you built a house/efficiency machine and one day you wake up and it's a prison that's not as flexible as you want. That's another thing I'm trying to keep in mind (I'm putting together a new similar team for this fall) - how do you keep the team agile and ready to shift when priorities shift? It could be as easy as accepting a little bit more churn & letting people go when they don't fit what's going on, but it's hard to let go of people you've trained and know well. I felt a friendship connection with my entire team, in hindsight I think that was a mistake too.

Those are some thoughts haha - what have you found so far? Are you experiences lining up with mine? What kind of roles are you hiring for?

author: Zach Hughes
content:
You're getting pretty granular with all this which can be useful, but might be worth zooming out a touch. The most meaningful collaborations I've had have been from me producing work that earns the respect and appreciation of my peers. The work itself is the alignment optimizer and the collaboration has almost always been downstream of that. I think its much harder to find alignment with 100 cold calls (which I've also tried). I think looking for a balance between producing music you really love and are proud of and cultivating a network of potential artists you would want to collaborate with is a good way of being. Which might be exactly what you're doing. Idk without more context.

Could be helpful to think of it like a conversation and maybe you need to make the first move. Have you tried commenting on other artists work you come across online that you find compelling? Not in a spammy juice the numbers kinda way but more of a conscious attitude towards how you choose to travel online. I see that all the time leading to collaboration between artists.

author: Zack Hames
content: If the alternative is to back home, I’ll try to offer some advice from personal experience. I moved to Richmond, VA for a year, got a job at a hotel doing audio visual. I quit my first commercial/post production gig doing ads full time. It was the worst but I was determined to keep working in music, and try to get integrated in the scene/studio world. It was a serious low for my mental health, the job was terrible, I was struggling and scraping by without any pay off. To make a long story short, I applied for a job back home at a big corporate company with a full time composition/post production gig, on a whim - I didn’t think it would get me anywhere. 3 months later I got the job and went back home after a year. I was out of the music scene back home at this point, and it took another year of reconnecting and working hard on my craft with friends who were willing to let me record their bands for the price  of drums heads and guitar strings, and honestly, those two things combined with some luck put me in a very secure and creative place, now making records for bands again that are paying decently well to boot. I don’t know how far you are in your career/journey, but I’m barely anything and have been recording for 15 years. It took me 5 years out of school to get barely a living wage and working lots of different types of audio jobs while making records, to get to a comfortable place emotionally, creatively, and financially. I’d bet almost anybody in this discord has a very similar story. It takes a long time and like others have said, there’s no one way to get there. Just keep doing you and trying to work on things that you enjoy.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
10 is better than none. But sounds like you get reallly invested in the process, and I’m assuming you’re trying to milk every song/production/mix for everything it’s worth. Might be helpful to just do less, and do more of them. It’s working through a vast body of a work that you start to learn the essential elements, what the beginning and end of the process looks and feels like, and how to manage yourself throughout. 
I wouldn’t tell everyone to care less, but seems like that’s the one thing that you need to break yourself of. So find a way to do less, so you can do more.
