author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Jeremy Klein  yeah its definitely building toward passive income. even a big big hit will mean a sizable few checks and then a looong tail of smaller ones. 

real world example: i co-wrote, produced and mixed this song "fine by me" by andy grammer. i have four points on the master (3 as producer, 1 as mixer). the song was a decent sized Hot AC hit back in like 2012, and has gone double platinum since then. this is partially because the song did decently well as a single at radio, and partially because he has continued to have follow up hits and continues to tour. his fans still stream his older music. 

the first few royalty checks (starting in like 2014), were low five figures twice a year (again, that's from a *four* point royalty). now it's probably a couple thousand a year (like 1k, twice a year).

this is, again, a double platinum song from 10 years ago, from an artist that has a loyal fanbase. the song actually didn't go double platinum until 5 years after it came out (continued streaming).

author: ALXCPH
content:
For the kind of chops that your description seems to hint at, i would say it is all about tieing technique to your ears. (Assuming, you can already hum a melody on the spot and are not tone deaf) 

I wouldnt worry too much about theory and super correct technique. 

The best Way to get anywhere on an instrument is by Playing it, and doing in consistently. Set some realistic goals and just get going, vocabulary and technique Will come naturally if you just keep Playing. 

Fuck Playing scales and inversions and all that for now. 
Just go learn a metric ton of songs and melodies and learn to play them together. Do it by Ear. It Will be tough in the beginning, but you Will get very decent quickly if you just do the most important Thing, which is being consistent.

I would reccomend setting a low minimum to do everyday to keep a realistic goal that you can keep, rather than a higher on you miss every now and then. You can always add more practice but it sucks to miss out on it.

Start with song you want to Sound like and then you can slowly branch out when the style become second Nature for you. 

Sadly there are no tricks or hacks or whatever youtube wants you to beleive to get their clicks. Its all about muscle memory and developing your ears together. And not to Sound like 4 bar loop, but consistency, and do it a lot. I cannot stress that enough. ❤️

author: LAPhill
content:
Jumping in way late to this conversation, but some thoughts:

I'm broadly on board with @Rollmottle 's sentiments that no one is owed anything, especially in this line of work. That said, all music industry professionals, from mastering engineers to songwriters to musicians, increasingly are in a place where they need to prove why they're worth a premium cost. Premium is no longer newbie engineer vs. Serban, it's free plugins (or the artist's friend with a laptop full of cracked software) vs someone with reps at all. Maybe right now, the "premium" cost of engineering is minimum wage, but that is sadly still much more expensive than slapping CLA vocal and Ozone on your track with well-produced Splice loops. So why is your service worth more than that? It's an honest question that we all face.

I believe in the value of educating a client in why what we do costs what it does, but I'm not going to lose sleep over someone that can't see it. I see a ton of up-and-comers over valuing their worth and losing out on gigs because they don't understand how far they have to go. Engineers are often just as guilty at overvaluing themselves as artists are at undervaluing them. 

The one thing that does seem to still hold true in 2023 is that people that are doing consistently good work keep getting hired. And track records of reliability, decent (not even great!) work, and some credits that someone's heard of are all things to point to when talking about price. @Deleted User made a point of someone wanting him, but not seeing his value, and that's a particularly tough spot. Sometimes, you've just got to walk away from those people, as good as it feels to be in demand by someone.

author: LAPhill
content:
I know I'm an outlier here as a composer, but I very much feel the spirit of the question and would like to offer a few thoughts. My job is about realizing someone else's vision and pushing that to be the best it can be. If you're being hired as a producer, then like me, you have to believe that you're being hired for your taste and perspective. So the question is, why doesn't it feel good to you? Is there something undiscovered that could make it better?

I've written a lot of music that's outside of my aesthetic or personal tastes. But if I'm on the project, I'm going to be 100% invested in helping make that thing what it needs to be. There's a way into music that's outside of your vibe - sometimes it's getting excited about new techniques, sometimes it's exploring a genre you're unfamiliar with, and sometimes it's just because the people you're making music with are a good hang. Sometimes, the role of a composer (or producer) is to take their vision and find the version of it that **does **get you excited. We've probably all had that experience of "I really never listen to X, but this one song/artist is just undeniable." So strive for that.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Absolutely @Nomograph Mastering i’ve got some perspective on this as I teach production and engineering as a visiting lecturer. The worst lectures (when I started) were just dense information with very little active element for the students. They had the info presented to them so that was learning, right? Of course, that was the wrong approach, and the more i’ve just provided broad themes to the group - i.e. make the sounds in front of you “angry, happy, distant, close” or “we will record/mix/master an EP within the next few weeks” the better the sessions go, and the more inquistive the students are to uncover the “learning” as they are doing.  I find making a fool of myself (“entertainment”) helps with this as it’s a useful tool to disarm the groups and build rapport. The more you can encourage students to learn from each other, and share the learning - prompted by me, the better the outcome is for everyone.

author: NoahNeedleman

Research degrees, however, and philosophy programs, will always be useful. Learning how to think about the process is more important than the process itself! 

My vote is forget the production emphasis. And along with Matt, my friends who studied ethnomusicology are some of the most interesting people and brilliant musicians to a person.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Quite a bit.

My learning is less music-focused these days, but I budget a lot of time for self-development and continued study.

Sometimes it's  20 min a day in a technical book that I'm reading. I move slowly and make sure I understand before I move on. It may take two months to complete, but I'm steady with it and I do a little bit most days. It's common for me to transcribe notes from high-density talks that I want to learn from and revisit them often over the span of a week. I'm constantly printing out my notes and reading material so that they're easy to revisit throughout the week.

I'm currently taking a project management course through MIT, which has been great. It's uncommon for me to do formal schooling these days, but this is work related and a direct application to my future capabilities that we thought would be beneficial for the company.

When I buy a new plugin (rare) I set aside time to go through it and turn every knob and try each feature to see what it's capable of. Learning a tool on the spot is a good way to kill the creative flow, so I do the exploration up-front when possible.

Often I'll have ideas for novel ways to use a tool (layering distortion, for example) and I'll set aside two hours to explore it and see what I find.

That said, I think my day-to-day may be quite different from a lot of folks here. My eggs aren't all in the business and pressures of record production, and so I rarely find myself buried in such commitments. I tend to keep "normal" business hours these days and keep a hard separation between my commitments and my leisure.

In fact I'd say that I'm actively structuring my life so that I can retain my leisure and don't find myself overwhelmed with commitments. That's a whole other story, though.

author: andrew_yv

Reasoning for moves thing you mentioned really resonates with something I experienced last year watching Shawn Murphy mix. He makes so few moves, and they’re so consistently effective and economical.
Based on that here’s a question: as far as I can tell, there are two legitimate reasons to make a move: to correct a technical issue that is detracting from the emotive expression of the piece, or to enhance that expression (these could be conflated). So far that’s been a good framework for me, but is there any other legitimate reason to do something to a song in mix, master, even arrangement? What am I missing?

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
I do the boring business structure stuff before getting into new year visions. Doing things like inventory helps set the vision. Updates to the spreadsheet for things sold and things bought. Aligning our insurance coverage with those updates. Review the year's chart of accounts to see what happened in the previous 12 months. How much did I spend on gear? Subcontracts? Session players? Advertising? From that it helps to form the goals/visions for the upcoming year. Lots of "that worked" and "don't do this again" and etc. 

Doing inventory this year made me realize that I needed to start renting out some less used production equipment. Have lots of items I need occasionally that could make a passive income when rented (carefully) to fellow audio dudes.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Personally it saddens me to see the continued disregard of the value of accurate and transparent credits by those in music. There's a reason the issue of credits is so messed up in this industry. I believe it's part systems, part incentives, but is also part cultural. I have hope that we can honor the contributions of our collaborators and build trust based networks. I don't see a solution to credits coming from anywhere outside of our tent. We do a disservice to the next generation of engineers, producers, and artists every time we obfuscate who contributed what to any given project.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@rae this is a great discussion! Totally agree about open communication. It's something Jon and I talk about a lot. Learning how to have difficult discussions (even just learning 10 different ways to communicate "that still isn't good, let's do another take") is such a huge part of what we do. But honest, open communication is almost always the best solution. 

The only other thing I'll add regarding @Zack Hames's initial question is that I find it super valuable to continue to do all kinds of different roles. If I've mostly been programming and finishing productions, I'll take some time to write a song and sing it myself, so I stay "in shape" with writing and recording vocals. If I don't do something myself, how can I empathize with someone? My communication style is always one of "I know how you're feeling and you can trust me because I've done it a ton."

author: peterlabberton
content:
In my experience, if I’m mixing and not also producing, there’s almost always (maybe just always always?) someone who can act as a tie breaker. The producer, lead singer/songwriter, guitar dude who is clearly leading the charge creatively, a manager, etc. etc. who you can turn to in order to give definitive direction... maybe during covid this is more difficult as I feel that often can become clear organically in the room.

If it’s truly a situation where there are contradictory/unproductive notes coming in, maybe either a) tell them they need to decide amongst themselves and then give you a clear list of notes, or b) take the lead yourself and really push for what you feel serves the song best/explain why the sax can’t be 10x louder than the lead vocal? Which option is best I’d say depends on your relationship with them, how much of a lead you want to take creatively, how confident you are in making the right choices for this song, etc. etc.

At least that’s what I’d do. 🤷🏻‍♂️ @cian riordan might have better advise for these situations!

author: cian riordan
content: I saw this mentioned on one of the vocal production episodes and I don't fully agree with it. If you had a perfect reflective surface that reflected back at a 180-deg angle into the null of the mic, that might be the case. But thats very rarely what happens in the real world. The cardioid pattern is shaped like a kidney and does stretch beyond the x-axis of the diaphragm, ultimately picking up lots of reflections from behind the plane of the capsule. Put a condenser microphone on a floor tom, under a cymbal and you'll hear what I mean. Or try singing into the backside of one. It sounds awful. Often, its the shittiest of the phasey reflections that get in through the back, so it's definitely worth treating. To your point, still lots of value in making sure behind the singer is treated as well as those reflections will likely be much more broadband. But given the size of this space (it small), I'd use all the help I could get in there.

author: Adam Thein
content:
My main tip for using Live live is try and replace as many third party plugins as you possibly can with stock, freeze as much as you can, and most of the latency you experience is going to be coming from internal delay compensation vs I/O latency.  If you are able to optimize your sets as much as possible, you can probably get away with running everything without offloading DSP to a UAD system.  If you are already in that ecosystem by all means!

I built a live set similar to what you have going based off of Daniel Mintseris Lynda (now LinkedIn Learning) videos that were amazingly helpful.  Also in my case I made samplers whenever possible of 3rd party synths if the patch didn't have a ton of modulation internally.  But yeah bottom line is keep an eye on your total device latency on groups (hovering over a group will display the total delay compensation/latency calculation in the Status Bar).

If you have any other questions for me feel free to DM!

Edit: we used a rackmount X32 for in ears that also served double duty as the audio interface running 16 i/o at 48khz and were able to do it on a 2015 macbook with minimal latency

author: Deleted User
content:
10% of my income comes from my day job 90% comes from music/audio. But 50% of my music income are gigs that I’m taking to pay the bills, the rest are projects that I feel somewhat passionate, or very passionate about. 

The living expenses have increased due to inflation and I’m also trying to save up money to get a car, so I am thinking about quitting my current day job to get another day job that will give me more hours. 

On months that I couldn’t make my ends meet, I did little things like snow shoveling for neighbors’ houses. I have not done lawn mowing but any one time gig with no schedule commitment can be a good option. The reason why I had to do this is because my day job wouldn’t give me any more hours. 

My issue lately has been the fact that I live in a very expensive city (Boston, MA), and I am barely making it work. More than 50% of the work I do heavily relies on being on-site (recording, live sound, and some parts of the production process).  If I moved further out from the city- the rent would not get cheaper enough to justify getting a car for the commute. And if I moved out of state to somewhere like Albany, NY or Rhode Island- I will be giving up huge part of my clientele and half of my income. So I thought a better option would be to get another day job that will help me stay where I’m at right now.

In your case- being a bad singer might actually be more useful than tryna be a good one! Some of my fav producers can’t sing a lick but they still know how to coax attitude or timing or whatever from a performer. 

One of the wildest things you learn when studying voice is that because it’s an involuntary muscle, you can’t train it like you do most of your body. You have to trick it, tell it weird shit, THINK weird shit, and none of it is technical, it’s all VISUAL. I remember my first vocal teacher (at 16) telling me to “imagine the note as a spinning silver ball in front of your mouth” AND IT WORKED.

It’s just also a very specific market with very unique parameters and people, so how a software company is run won’t be a one to one parallel on how you should run a production career. A bit like a pet store owner outlining how to take care of a new puppy to a person that just bought a Canary. Definitely give it food and water, but there are some specifics that require a very different tact.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've got a question for the crew that hopefully will lead to some interesting discussion but honestly could use some outside perspective here.

How important is it that we as collaborators come to a consensus on what feels good for the production of a song? Let's say you as a producer are not vibeing with the artist's direction / vision for a song, but the artist feels very passionate about their vision. You help them realize their vision all the way through and it still doesn't feel good to you or any other involved party other than the artist. What then?

I'm curious to hear some thoughts on the producer's perspective and the artist's perspective. To paint the extremes a little bit; at what point does being disagreeable as a producer (when dictated by your own taste / gut / intuition) become a hindrance to the project or unprofessional? And for the artist at what point are you getting in your own way so to speak and diminishing the potential outside contribution from collaborators that could level up your work?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Couple things from my perspective. 
1) it’s our job as producers to make the artist’s vision a winner. If we haven’t done that, we’ve failed. Like when the artist asked for a wetter vocal, we don’t just crank the verb right? We make sure it’s not causing problems mucking up transients etc. same with instrumentation and all. 
2) it’s the artist we’re serving. So when we’re done and have gotten paid, they’re the ones who have to go out and tour it, promote it, share it with they’re moms and kids and SOs etc. They need to be happy with it. 
3) if we can’t make 1 happen, we make 2 happen and move on to the next one. 

Generally I find the more I’m able to serve the artist’s vision, over time the trust grows and they become more interested and even reliant on consensus. But there are always outliers songs and outlier clients and outlier collaborators and outlier artists. 

In the long run, ain’t we all just tryna get it right?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
First of all I like that you just assumed Rauirí’s premise. Cause I did too, and that makes me wonder if this particular paradox is innate in all of us musician/artist types. 

I do think your perspective is one way of getting at it. Learn grammar, write poetry and all that. There’s a lot of actors who have to learn the lines by rote before they can ever get at the heart of the material… often as a producer if I love a song, I have to listen to it many times before I start to see how to improve on it. 

But I think I know I was able to hold both reverence and a “fuck you i’m doing it my way” attitude from the get go. I’m not an icon, but I lived in that tension my whole life. Being a slave to the vision requires complete hubris *and* complete humility. 

Like all paradoxes, I don’t think one can give directions to it in pithy aphorisms.

author: Deleted User
content:
@joshbonanno said:

i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face... 

wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great. 

because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist. In some cases, even the intended audience. with that said, if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. 

/ might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it. 

so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. 

this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world. but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
It’s a lot harder to find a way to make something you think is bad work than to change it to something you “know” is good. 

And, not to be too diplomatic, currently I want my producers to be opinionated, my mixers to be intuitive, and my MEs to be humble. But when I was a young know-it-all artist, I just wanted them all to be clairvoyant. 

There’s a line here between doula & doctor that we all have to walk.

author: Deleted User
content:
I used to think that I knew what was wrong and just didn’t know how to fix it… But if I really knew what was wrong, I would have been able to fix it. Which made me realize if I don’t know how it’s wrong and why, I won’t be able to figure out what are things I could do to fix it. Which means I don’t know what is wrong with it. Anyone can tell when something’s not right, but knowing what exactly isn’t right comes with experience and practice. 

I think there is a difference between “I think there’s something wrong with X and I can’t really point out what it is. Could you have a listen and tell me what that might be?” or “I haven’t mixed it yet so if you can just give me feedback on the arrangement and vocal production that would be greatly appreciated” versus “it’s not mixed yet… so it’s going to sound like shit” 

One of my mentors from the past said “people have no ability to imagine what it may sound like later when you fix XYZ and rerecord XYZ, so either show it to them after you’ve done what you were going to do or just don’t say nothing. it makes their first experience of listening whatever you’re presenting way worse and lame-r”

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Dealt with a semi-similar situation last year, except I was not producing. My solution was to be polite but firm: I would weigh in on musical + sonic questions, but would not enter into band politics. They needed to make decisions, and once there was a decision, I would make sure it got done. I would do my best to keep things moving, but if the drama made things take longer + cost more, that was on them.

And then once that was clear, I did my best to keep being supportive to the music + the musicians.

author: Rob Domos
content: The mechanism make perfect sense if you have a good sense of molecular biology. In short, mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species as a biproduct of producing ATP and use an electron gradient in this process. Electromagnetic fields impact this electron gradient in a way that can increase the rate of ROS production, and ROS presence is basically inextricably tied to inflammation. Think about the word “inflammation” and what fire is fundamentally. Fire is oxygen rapidly deionizing things so fast that it forms a plasma. Similarly, when ROS increases inside of you, you’re literally lighting fire to microscopic particles inside of you. You are thus “inflamed”. It don’t feel good.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Not shit talking BBC, or my own products... but on a BIZ TIP for younger me out there: Don't assume there is no reason to push for players because you have great sequencing skills and $50k worth of sample libraries.  When the production company wants world-class sound, and it's your job to create the budget...   knowing that sample libraries can only take you so far is key to explaining to the client WHY they should allocate budget for humans. "I can create this with just the computer, and it will sound great....  but it won't sound like your example.  There's a real VALUE to humans playing the music and that extra 10% of the quality you're looking for requires a studio session with real players" 

Instant path to budget upgrade.  Suddenly the expense makes sense to them.  Now you get the pleasure of hiring all your friends and deliverying something that sounds top notch...  and you can take the client on a mind-blowing field-trip.  It took me years to learn this trick...   clients don't want to pay mountains of money extra for you to sit in front of your computer and massage CC lanes....  and if they have a mindblowing time in the studio and the track sounds ALIVE?  You win six different ways.

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: The only thing I have to contribute is I work with folks in the 23 - 35 age range regularly (Im 44) and younger people who are HUNGRY to move up and ahead in their career get easily frustrated that things don't just happen for them when they're feeling like they're sacrificing a lot for very little recognition. There is also a lot of pushing and pulling the artists to fit their expectations instead of serving the art and letting nature take its course. Specifically theres a lot of "I can't wait to help you realize the full expression of your music and art when we work together!!!!!!!!" kind of vibe which is great internally but puts off older artists a little bit. I've seen it a lot over the last couple years with young producers and engineers and I wonder if its because of the pandemic, honestly. The whole "check list to success" thing is another good point. Some things are not easily repeatable or scalable with the expectation of the same result every time.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I was going to discuss this a bit on my birthday, but a big part of the reason I give Cian so much guff on here publicly is because I saw a lot of pearl clutching for a second. “This producer works me too hard”, “this person insulted my hair, can I work with them” etc. 

A music career is rarely experienced entirely alone. You WILL have to deal with other people, and often time they’re… “artists”. They’ll be mercurial. They’ll be quirky. They’ll take work. And that’s ok. A huge part of making a living in this business is to learn how to stick to your guns without being just completely insufferable. 

I hate Cian’s speakers. I hate him even more. But he makes a mean martini, so I go over to his house for work, and even recommend him for things. That’s how the real world works. 

Find something in someone you like, and cultivate something interesting about yourself. Then go diamond.

author: Zack Hames
content: As an engineer/mixer, How do you keep the perspective of the musicians you work with? After so many of years of being on the recording side of the glass and recording myself every day, I find myself forgetting what it would be like to trust someone else to record or mix something I’m creating. A lot of my thought process is on “finishing” and “by any means necessary”. I often wonder if I’d be as open minded as a musician in a band in a studio as I try to encourage my clients to be. For example, using someone else’s gear, the engineer making bold mix decisions/production choices, adding parts, etc. obviously some of these boundaries should be set before you dive in deep into a project. What are things that the musicians are thinking/experiencing emotionally I might be overlooking?

Etc.) everyone is different and idk how you approach the deeper conversations but I’ve had bad experiences with being recorded so having those conversations could be good - not sure if this was what you were after but maybe food for thought 🤷🏻‍♀️

author: dominic_feverspeak
content: I feel all of this. I do a lot of tracking and it’s my favorite part of the process because interacting with the musicians during the moment of capture is really exciting to me. My two cents: if there isn’t a designated producer in the room and you’re fulfilling both the engineer/producer roles then trying to get from load in to recording as quickly as possible seems to work well - that way they can be witness and collaborator to any sonic changes. Like someone was talking about a producer who just dampened the toms right away - maybe that was necessary but if the artist hasn’t heard both options in the same room on the same song then they’re left with nothing but faith that this is the right decision. But if you just start recording quickly and then chime in with “hey, I feel like maybe the toms are ringing out for too long, can we try dampening them on this next take?” They’re probably more likely to try it out.

author: Zack Hames
content: This may be weird advice, but sometimes I just say “sure!” (Or completely disregard depending on context) To certain ideas or mix notes and choose not to address them again. It doesn’t always work but sometimes people just say stuff to say stuff, and they may listen to the mix several times again and get used to how it is and not even want the change later or remember they said anything. I know that may sound insulting but I just dealt with this exact thing, and that did save me a few times. If they brought it up again I tried to meet in the middle. I started experimenting with this once I realized being super honest/straight forward/transparent can actually slow down the process without any benefit. This may apply to more commercial productions where people don’t really want a “no” or a “why not” they just want a yes man and a person to get the job done. I hope that makes sense, I feel like some of the other options you’ve definitely already came up with. Sometimes making your case with the utmost confidence can also work! (Not something I do often but it absolutely can work)

author: cian riordan
content: Not a full-time mastering engineer, but I have prepped plenty of masters for vinyl reproduction. Typically, I would try and find a way to bring down the level significantly without changing the sonics too much. This is usually as simple as peeling back the limiter. I'll usually deliver for vinyl around -16 LUFS. There's really no reason for it to be any louder. And as for the output on limiters (assuming you're talking about non-vinyl preparation), I set mine at -0.1 dBFS and if asked to deliver MFiT, will set to -0.8 dBFS.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zakhiggins the best producers in the world are great because of this. getting the best out of an artist/ vocalist. your job should be getting the best performance. most young artists change their vibe around a fancy mic in a studio. some of them show up and kill it. your job is to adapt and find that vibe quickly, while being super comfortable. this job is way more psychology and vibe than technical know how!

we recorded the hives vocals on Tik Boom with an SM7 on a straight mic stand in front of Pelle's live wedge monitors. HE knew that's how he could rock out the most and get the best vocal.

eric valentine gave Adam from Taking Back Sunday a neumann hand held condenser on a long cable so he could move around the room and perform.

i just figured out how to edit them after the fact. they weren't as clean as standing in front of a U47 with a pop screen. but they sounded fucking awesome

author: peterlabberton
content: Personally, I don't really bother taking these kinds of notes while tracking. If I'm producing something myself, I prefer to just keep moving and try something, then move on as quickly as possible. If it needs to be redone for some reason, I'll just cook up a sound again and not get too hung up on whether it's identical or not—chances are if we're revisiting it, things could be improved anyway. If I'm engineering for someone else, I'll defer to them, but these are usually situations where things are even *more* time-sensitive (i.e. we're renting an expensive studio), and the situation is very unlikely to be recreated anyway. I was very lucky to have subbed in for @cian riordan with St. Vincent for a couple months in the early stages of this new record—nothing was documented (unless I grabbed a quick photo to cover my own ass), it was all just trying stuff, and if it worked it worked, if not, move on and forget it! Mixing is another story—in the (increasingly) rare instance when I'm mixing on a console, I'll figure out some way of recalling for that particular project. This is usually more or less @Rollmottle's method, except I go even more jank-ass and just scribble song names on a post-it and hold it in front of a piece of gear like a mugshot. Anything on the console is either stored in the console automation, or, like the most recent project I mixed on a console, I'll just calibrate all the faders and run stuff through it, but really *mix* in Pro Tools still. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: junior.frigo
content:
Hey all! Been loving the live shows but fairly new to the server so feel free to point me in the right direction if there's a better thread for my question. Wondering what tools and habits people are using for medium to long term planning and vision casting, for lack of a better term, especially when busy?

Had what I would consider my first really busy year as a producer last year. Worked on 75 songs, most of them full instrumental productions taking them from a demo, playing / recording everything, and often mixing. It was a really exciting year but I found I spent most of the time being reactive, rather than proactive, just trying to stay on top of getting things out the door on time! 

What do y'all do to make sure you get time thinking about what you'd like to see happen in your career (everything from people you want to work with, music you want to create, gear you want to purchase), and organize it in an actionable way so that your time spent making stuff for other people also takes you where you want to go long-term? Thanks!

author: ALXCPH
content: I can only agree with what’s been said. I did the same last time I was on tour. Also sometimes simpler = better. 100 elements might work nicely in your favourite headphones but with a live system. Usually only the necessities and maby a few ear candy stuff is enough. You don’t really need 13 different synths playing the same part! Also if you are playing and inside venue that has a little bit of size to it, you don’t need as much reverb, cuz it happens naturally. If you don’t know what sound system they are running or have any contact to the sound guy, just make sure it at least sounds somewhat good in mono, just to be safe. Also make sure the backing tracks have “room” for the live instrumentalist! That way the sound guy can turn it up without drowning out the band. 🙂

author: cian riordan
content: And it will go down and down the chain. Why hire a mixing engineer when the producer gets it so close? Or why hire a producer when the artists demos are so good that you can just release that? Why have a songwriter when the artists just write their own songs? I don't disagree with you at all. I know that this is the case and am sure that my pirate ship is sailing in shallow waters... it's only a matter of time before I wash ashore. While I do applaud the evolution of the music making process and the ingenuity of the players moving the needle, if I *were* to make a stupid line graph, I don't think the quality of the work will rise as fast as high as the increase in efficiency... it's likely to invert.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i'm not actually quite saying that. i'm saying that most projects will only need one "outside ear" at the end of the process. mixer/ finisher/ mastering engineer will be one role rather than two. 

mastering used to be about technical knowledge for delivering different physical media. it was also nice to have one extra set of ears on a project after the tracking/mixing engineer (who was the same person from the 1930s to 1980s). but now we're going back to the tracking engineer and mixing engineer being the same person (possibly the producer and writer as well). there really only needs to be one more step. mixer/ mastering/ finishing gonna be the same role.

also fully agree that quality will continue to decline as more technically untrained people make music. 

btw i'm not arguing good or bad for any of this. just seems likely that's where we're headed

author: Deleted User
content:
Hmm. I’m a young person in early 20s, so also seeking advice/people’s thoughts on this.

Wouldn’t you say it would be better to be decent at all of the things mentioned above for paths like producer? It isn’t required to be good at all of things because hiring other people is always an option, but starting out- I’m working with projects with lower budgets where people can barely afford to hire a producer. 

I want to have one strong path, and strength within those skill sets- but I feel like being well rounded wouldn’t hurt if there is one clear path I want to work on. And it seems to me that the path encompasses many different skills. For example, I would work on my instrumental skills, engineering skills, and arrangement skills- but I wouldn’t necessarily seek to pursue these career paths unless I was asked to because I know that primary focus is in production. I would still take gigs in different areas if the pay my bills, but if I get to a point where I can make full living exclusively from production work- I will not take other gigs unless I’m passionate enough to the point I wouldn’t mind doing them for free. To sum up my thoughts or desires on this- I want to build proficiencies in all areas because I believe they are part of the path I want to go through. Although I wouldn’t necessarily pursue a career in those areas I’m developing but I will still take the gigs until I’m paying all my bills and able to build proper savings solely from one thing I would ultimately want to do. 

It may sound like I’ve already made up my mind, but I’m eager to hear people’s thoughts on this because this is something I’ve been thinking about for a long time especially because I hear people say “niche down” or “focus on one thing”.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Just got this same spec also last weekend.  About a week in, it's definitely a little crowded for finishing work in my opinion but I'm use to working on a 1440p 24" monitor.  I can always HDMI I figure if I need the extra real estate.

The only acustica plug I run regularly is Ruby 2 - seems to cause pretty drastic spikes on the CPU short term in Ableton (running rosetta mode and VST3 by the way) but then it levels out.  In general I've been super impressed with the performance vs my desktop.  I'd say for my mixes it runs maybe 80% as well on large projects (75+ tracks, lots of processing) which was more than I was expecting.  Smaller projects and productions and softsynths it absolutely chews through compared to my desktop.

Was just trying out a little mix in Studio One just on the 14" and it felt very cramped to me.  I think it'd be hard to completely mix at this resolution but again it probably has more to do with what I'm used to.  Would definitely recommend a separate display if you are going to be doing all your work on it.

author: ALXCPH
content: our whole tuning systems is based on the harmonic series of stacking 5ths. because nature gives us exactly that through the overtone series. but the higher you go the more "out of tune" it goes. back in the day, before we were able to make octave, and divide them into 12 notes, you would have the concept of a low E and a High E as they wouldnt sound "in tune" when trying to find the octave though stacking 5ths or thirds or fourths or what ever interval people tried to use. we chose 5ths at is was the closest one to looping while being somewhat in tune, and the we invented 12 tone equal temperment and made compromises on each note so that the notes would loop every 12 tones.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Interesting. I think any craft can be elevated to an art form, and the crafter to artist. 
Creating something from nothing is a fine distinction for an artist, especially in music, and I can stand by that with you. I think your point is well made. 
But as someone who has worn all the hats, (writer, singer, songwriter, composer, performer, producer, mixer, sideman, engineer, “artist,” music director, I’ve even mastered a few records,) I would say the work of any of these hands can be an art form in and of itself. 

That’s the journey of a craftsmen I think- to become an artisan.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Schools not important. Education is.

I went to a trade school for audio, a working recording studio that also had very well made and structured classes, walked away with a portfolio and having had been lead and assistant engineer on dozens of sessions. I don’t blame anyone for hating their school, hating the idea of school, etc. I just got lucky and I owe my entire career to that experience. 

Audio is not a field where the piece of paper means a god damn thing. It might help you when applying for more corporate adjacent jobs but I work full time, salary, for the production team for marketing at a huge company, im probably the only person in the entire marketing department that doesn’t have an actual college degree.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
This was lovely to read. I’ve definitely been there on prod projects, and others. I’ll always allow projects to swell to fit the allowed time, which invariably adversely affects the quality of the work.

My vice is a deep seated tendency towards fucking around given the chance, and the energy and time that goes into that fuckery or exploration of alt options (which are NEVER as good as the first thing that inspires me) will ALWAYS have been better spent realising the first idea fully in the initial moment of inspiration.

I know this intellectually, but here I am at 7am voice noting out the structure of a pitch due today - doing the mapping out I should’ve done 4 days ago rather than trying out different drums, micing, guitar tones, etc etc on a 16 bar loop.

If anyone has a solution to this, I’d love to know how you’ve beaten your bad habits into submission.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not an answer to your question, but reminded me of a dynamic that I observed in my time assisting at major London studios:

There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

Of course there are going to be bell ends from every country (and there were plenty of exceptions - I've had many incredible sessions with North American clients, and some gross sessions with UK clients too), but it happened enough to wonder whether maybe it's a cultural thing?

Does this hold water with you US folks’ experience? FWIW, I can’t imagine anyone in this Discord treating anyone like that, let alone their colleagues. And of course, my personal experience is probably weighted 80/20 UK/international.

author: austenballard
content:
> There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

I want to add to what Ruairí and Matt B said with another perspective. I've had the privilege of working in some very professional settings, where everyone needs to fade into the background to do their jobs properly, and that's absolutely the case at higher levels. And it makes things work. And everyone's cool about it.

But much of my work has been as producer, assistant producer or project manager/fixer for people working at decidedly lower levels. 

And idk how it is in other countries, but we have a glut of people here in the US who have a certificate from a for-profit recording school that says they know what they're doing, who think they're *the shit* for being in the room with some viral star off YouTube/Instagram/TikTok. But don't know how to use a damn patch bay. 

And when you're on the come up, especially as a writer or producer, you interact with a lot of these people, and you get REALLY sick of them REALLY fast. So that might be the source of some of the condescension you see. It's hard not to get jaded when you have to wade through so much incompetence. I feel like a bitter old man just typing this paragraph tbh but I hope I'm not the only one with this experience.

author: cian riordan
content: When I first got hired by Eric as his assistant, I had already built a multi room studio complex and was making a living producing and engineering records. When I landed in LA for the first session, my mindset was “I can’t wait to show off all the knowledge and experience I had.” I very quickly ran up against the “nobody-gives-an-absolute-fuck-what-I-have-to-say-about-anything” wall. It was very clear that I was there to sit in the back of the room until I was asked to do something… order food, help with a mic setup, shuffle cars in the parking lot, etc. Not to mention working for someone like Eric who is extremely self sufficient… he was terrible at asking me to do things. It was always just quicker for him to do it… even if it meant getting up from the seat and walking all the way across the studio to adjust something. I made the absolute mistake in my second or third week of suggesting something to the drummer in the band after a performance. Eric overheard and pulled me aside. Basically said something along the lines of “yo, you really can’t do that. If you have an idea, run it through me. Absolutely inappropriate, however well intentioned it was. This was really deflating to me. I went from running the show at my own place to spending 14 hrs a day waiting for something to do.

author: LAPhill
content:
This has happened several times in the classical world, where unfinished works are completed either by apprentices of the composer, or someone that took it upon themselves to complete the work. More recently, when James Horner died during the scoring of The Magnificent Seven, his assistant/arranger finished the score. 

The difference between this and the pop example is there is no AI technology used to imitate the person, which feels like a parlor trick to me. I am all for finishing unfinished art, but unless there was an express wish from the artist to use their voice via AI tech, then I say make it known what it is. Finish the production by bringing in other people to celebrate the spirit of the original voice. Pay tribute. Sort of like Japanese Kintsugi, where you're drawing attention to what it's not to elevate what it is. (This is not the intention of kintsugi exactly, but I can't think of a better metaphor at the moment).

author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple of reasons:
1) it’s just easier to carry around, easier to pack, and doesn’t take up  a usb port which are at a premium on the mb pro.
2) I was working with a lot of producers that were just monster fast right off the trackpad on the actual laptop. There was a bit of “lemme see if I can do that” out of sheer boredom.
3) THEORETICALLY, the trackpad offers a higher ceiling than the trackball, especially with better touch tool. The way I worked on the trackball was using the buttons to swap through tools and it allowed me to work really really quick. The track pad has WAY more ways to chord and double/triple 2/3/4/5 finger tap/swipe to program oft used key commands. I’m giving it a year or two to become intuitive.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
In most instances, I feel I am fairly remunerated for my work at this stage. On the way to this point though, I did the grind and experienced the impact of that lifestyle on my mental and physical health, and on my personal life and relationships.

I'd rather people coming up now wouldn't have to endure the shitness that can abound, and to that end I sourced thoughts from a bunch of engineers, assistants, producers, mixers, and studios in the UK at the end of last year.

The list below was assembled from those conversations, and details some basic working conditions for music technicians working on a day rate basis (runners, assistants, tape/PT ops, engineers - not mixers, MEs, producers, or songwriters) that would bring us more in line with what have long been established and taken for granted by clients and employers in the comparable industries of theatre and film.

I'm not talking about bringing the industry to its knees here - just about establishing basic working conditions to safeguard the mental and physical health of our friends and colleagues.

I recognise that there are conditions specific to our industry and the nature of our work that would make some of these points less than straightforward to establish, so I'd love to hear everyone's thoughts on the below - whether they're reasonable, actionable, etc.

Pick some holes.

author: Deleted User
content:
another one I’m thinking is how a lot of artists are funding their projects through gofundme or kickstarter type ask. 

The issue a lot of times is that we (musicians, engineers, producers, writers) are getting paid by artists paying out of pocket, whom also need a day job to support what they do most of the times. So what ends up happening is that we’re struggling relying on making a living paid by those who are also struggling. 

The culture of music should shift towards the direction where if the artist is able to provide enough values for people to want to hear more work from them, then people should be down to fund it. The issue is that everyone’s expenses are more likely going to be prioritizing commodities over intangible products like music. NFT seemed to attempt commodifying music, but just like modern art paintings- they just became a method of investment for monetization, avoiding taxes, or status; nor it was accessible enough for everyday people to want to get into it.

author: peterlabberton
content: And also, just listen! Like, get rid of anything visually distracting and listen through the song. Try to be just a listener and not a mixer—find the spots where something is either clashing or not speaking enough. Clashing: turn down the less interesting or important thing. Not speaking enough: turn up the compelling thing. Also pay attention to transition moments. Get the chorus to hit by turning the synth pad down leading into it, etc.

author: Barbara
content:
Even though I understand where you come from with this - I guess everyone relates and/or feels more emotionally connected with some projects than others - I think we should own what we do. If you're recording/mixing/producing, do it as best as you can. That can mean passing it on to someone else (and handle this part with care, in my opinion, is also a part of the job). But if you end up going all the way, it still is a worthy project, you should still give it 100% of yourself. Learn something new and useful. And if you do, you should be proud of having your name on something you know you gave your best (even if the rest of it wasn't ideal, your part was the best you could do, at least in a certain moment in time).

So, I'm all for: work in it, own it. But make sure you do your best all the times and always learn something.

author: BatMeckley
content:
By all accounts she’s one of the best vocal producers/engineers around, so I’ve never had the chance to work with her. Can’t speak for her techniques. 

Revoice something I almost never use. In standalone melodyne on a lot of pop tracks if it’s a centered double I’ll make it spot dead on, almost to the point where it’s phasing, to beef up a lead to cut through a mix. If it’s singer songwriter Elliot smith vibe I’ll hard tune the double and for a tonal center and then let the lead breathe more to keep the character. Left Right doubles  you can’t tune as hard because they’ll start to collapse to mono which defeats the whole purpose.  

So again, it’s usually about working backwards from what you want, what it’s supposed to be, than it is about any one technique

Also the majority of records I mix, I don’t do any of the tuning or editing so I guess it’s more about the rare times I’m tracking/producing.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So the producer of *Abstract* is (was?) the editor of *Wired* magazine and he and David Chang were doing a SXSW talk on their upcoming joint venture.

I'd been intrigued by a 2016 feature that David published in *Wired* called *David Chang's Unified Theory of Deliciousness*. Silly name, but a stimulating read.

In the article David describes his epiphany about how popular flavor profiles in recipes re-occur across cultural boundaries. How a Chinese spicy pork sausage and rice cake has the same fundamental flavor profile as an Italian ceci e pepe and they share underlying structures that are expressed differently in their respective cultural incarnations. In math this would be called an isomorphism.

Well this immediately rang to true to me because I'd observed the same thing in music. I thought about this article for a year. Finally I saw that they were giving a talk in a hotel showroom with 500 people in attendance and made it a point to attend.

When the open mic was passed around I asked my prepared question, expressing my admiration for their insight and how it was applicable to other domains beyond food. I asked them if they'd had any additional insights on this phenomena since publishing the article.

They both looked to each other, didn't say a word, and then proceeded to ask for the next question 😕.

To this day I have no idea what happened.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Seriously though....  this was inspired by a pop track string/winds  arrangement.  You'd think "well of course all the sample libraries I bought can do that just as well"  but not imxp....  its that the sample libraries can do "an adequate" job and satisfythe need.  But once you hire world-class players and play it live into mics....  for me it was instantly "we could've bought every sample library and programmed for days but never gotten this quality" in the tiny details.  The bow sounds. The players breathing together. Their adaptation to dynamics. The aleatoric sections where advanced techniques were improvised. Samples can be amazing and do things humans can't...  but the inverse is also true.  There are many context where it's got to be live players, or else your track is just "adequate"

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I don’t think this is a hot take. Wind & String instruments and the human voice are all kinda impossible to make into a virtual instrument in a completely human sounding way. 

But, a world-class ensemble is often a little out of reach for a lot of self-producing artists and young folks just getting into it, and while something to strive for, shit talking BBC orchestra in this context feels shitty. 

The key is to do interesting things with what you have. Can’t hire the LSO? Make something intentional that gives the same feeling if not the same Sonics.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I'll refrain from addressing the producer angle, but I often wonder -- is it actually useful to have this preconceived notion of "your sound" or "the sound we are going for"? Or is it better to follow the art as it unfolds in front of you? Were the records you mentioned made with an endpoint in mind, or are they simply very effective representations of those artist's tastes?

Genuinely curious what the producers here feel

author: cy (sigh)
content:
1st thing I'd recommend is listening to the Tape Notes podcast. they interview the artists and producers to break down the processes and stories behind the tracks. 

I got quite a bit of confidence in that respect from listening to those . especially ppl  that come back multiple times. I don't even necessarily listen to everyone's music, I'm often more intwrested in their personal approaches - especially since lost are folk who we'd consider "established"  and what I found to be true for most of them is they split into 2 main camps with most of us dancing between them. 

a) have 0 clue wtf they're going for a lot of the time. kind of going with the flow of whatever is happening /they're feeling in the moment. very similarly to people starting out or me. the approach can vary wildly and a whole concept can be born of something seemingly unimportant at any given moment. 

b) there's an outline that comes to mind early and might give some direction. whether that's thematically or sonically. how tightly they stick to this can vary a lot depending on the artist. 

I think there are many factors that come into play - how good and ready the team they have is might be one of the most important imo. that's both for the creative side and admin side. 

as far answering  your questions as a producer, it depends. 
some artist I work with will literally dream up the whole production and I'm kind of facilitating and bringing it into the real world. others will come with loose ideas and others will show up with absolutely nothing and go off the feeling in the moment. some are more involved than others in the production

your relationship with them is probably the biggest factor in knowing how far you can push their creatively bounderies. 
same artist that dreams up their production usually gives me free range to try whatever I want when the session is over and I've overhauled whole songs.  recently a post-punk ish artist picked up a video game ost /jazz fusion prod I was sketching

author: spectrummasters
content:
Fun . Can dig it . I’ve got a 90s midi style production setup alongside my contemporary one . Akai s3000 slaves to the MPC 2000 . Into mixer . 
Only major difference to writing in the daw is timing of the mpc. Be aware if you’re tracking it into your daw it won’t line up on the grid as its timing drifts . So if you like easy grid based edits of overdubs etc it gets a little more complicated than usual . I wasted a bit of time trying to work out the problem then slaving the mpc to daw MTC which then just removes the mpc swing which is counterproductive . So yeah , if at any point it’s gonna be tracked into the daw familiarise and strategise for that asap in the process .

I had another job up until the pandemic actually, was working 20+ hours a week, and doing college while working on music, then the pandemic hit and the place I worked at shut down, the business is fully closed now but that's another story. Basically long story short, I'm actually kinda full time music right now while finishing off my college degree. That's my long ass story anyways, since you asked 🤣

author: antoniohannamusic
content:
Hey Rob, so I did a video explaining it (using the older version of the plugin) but in short you create two sessions, an Artist Session and a Producer Session.

The Producer session: Sends full mix + click to artist and has a receive channel

The Artist Session:

Receives full mix, then sends back the performance dry (vocal, guitar, bass, trumpet, you name it)>

In the producer session you then offset your local playback by the roundtrip latency, so you're hearing the artist perform "in time" with your session,

You then just nudge the clips back after each take 😄

Creatively I feel like taking time away is always helpful.

author: Slow Hand
content: Question for the writer/producers here. When you're arranging a song, how much do you think about simplicity and the directness of the writing versus layering on a bunch of parts? When I say simplicity I'm thinking of a song like "Back In Black" by AC/DC which is stripped-down, direct, and has no extra frills. All the parts serve a strong purpose and support that feel. Great song. Very powerful. On the other hand, I think of an equally good song with a big, layered, arrangement with lots of multi-tracked parts, stacked vocals, etc ala "Rock With You" by Michael Jackson. The song has tons of parts all coming in and out. Equally as compelling.

author: Slow Hand
content: So I'm also trying to think ahead to tracking and production. I like big orchestrations, but I also want to be really minimal and open. I'm typically not the kind of producer who's gonna stack 12 vocals and 4 guitars in the hunt for a massive sound. Not unless they're all doing different things. When y'all are layering parts how are you approaching it? I'm always asking myself, do we really need this? However I love all the ear-candy that you can get with that kind of approach, so I want to encourage that and leave the door open.

author: oaklandmatt

author: peterlabberton

If they’re comfortable doing that and know what they want, I’ll go chase down synth sounds or comp drums or whatever.

author: dylannash
content:
What are some of your favourite elements of your prod/mix templates? I currently have a separate production/writing template and then another for mixing but I’m trying to hybridise and streamline them a little more to get faster results and hopefully focus on the song. Also, most of the songs I mix tend to be one’s I’ve written and produced as well, so hoping to cut down on session set-up time.

Some of mine are an instant “duck bus”, which I picked up from Ian Kirkpatrick. It’s a pre-loaded aux with something like LFO Tool or shaper box on it, so you can quickly route and uniformly make things side chain.

Another quick workflow thing I love is having Pro Tools audio playlists with a bunch of reverse sweeps, impacts and other transition fx/ear candy hidden and ready to go in the session, so you can quickly try out a bunch. 

I also have the trim plugin added as the first and last plugin on every new track preset, as I use them to quickly manage the gain in and out of each track and so I don’t have to search for them constantly.

Ozone Spectral shaper on some music busses and as a replacement for Soothe on the mix bus has also been a real win (thanks Jon!) Although these sorta things aren’t turned on whilst writing as they have a ton of latency.

Keen to hear what you all find useful!

author: Josh
content:
I mean, yes and no. 

It’s not about if it’s just good or bad. 

It’s about if it matches with the audience. 

There are great songs that can’t make it on the radio. There are great songs that can’t be played live because they don’t translate with the audiences energy. They still aren’t bad songs. Their intent is just different. 

I think you’re mistaking the idea of “bad” for “wrong”. 

There aren’t bad songs. There’s just wrong songs. Not every choice made during writing/production/mixing is going to resonate with everyone.

author: cian riordan
content: I think it's safe to say that different roles have various degrees of influence on the success of a record. It's silly to think that a mastering engineer spending a day mastering an album will have as much impact as an artist spending years writing & producing that very record. I also think all of these various roles within the record making process have evolved over time... the creative roles have become more technical and the technical roles have become more creative. Only a matter of time before the venn diagram below becomes one circle.

author: Eric Martin
content:
As long as there’s someone out there that has listened/worked on more music than the person who is the Mixer or Producer and has a “technically better” or more accurate playback system than said producer there will be a viable job for the ME when it comes to releasing music IMO, not everyone will pay to do it, but the people who want to put out the “best work” will, the job will change, it already has many times, but the responsibility will stay.

FWIW at Abbey Road in the 50’s/60’s the new engineers started in the cutting room so that they learned exactly what was possible to put on the records as it was cut, then they gradually worked  their way back from cutting to working in the room with an artist.

I think this process is insanely valuable, I just did my first “true” tracking session in over a year and after mainly Mastering and Mixing for the last year/two my tracking mixes sounded dang finished.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Overall everything that's compatible works great through Rosetta, but there are a few software holdouts that I'm unable to get to work right now, so I'm not migrating any of my in-progress projects to the new computer yet. I'm using the new computer solely for new ideas right now.

The software I'm not getting to work are the few Waves plugins I use, *Wavesfactory Spectre*, and... I think that's it? The big holdout for me was the NI Massive X synthesizer, which *just* got Rosetta compatibility *today*. That was probably the big "can't live without" thing for me.

I even got my UA Apollo to work, though it seem to have an additional 2 ms or so of input latency, so I think it'll have to be optimized better.

I haven't tried installing Pro Tools yet. Honestly, if Pro Tools never touches my new computer it will probably be better off for it. I loathe Digidesign's software.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I’m coming to an impasse; I’m in a band that works a lot and I record our stuff, and I get a lot of work Mastering and Mixing. The more I do that the more I realize that the production and tracking are significantly more important than MIX/MSTR for the “success of the song”.

I’d love to put my hands on outboard mastering gear but I have a few upgrades that I would like to do for my tracking situation(full live band tracking) and the costs are about the same for either, I get a little less work tracking but it’s like 40% Mastering 35% Tracking and 25% Mixing work.

Most mixes I do all in the box and the little outboard I have helps shape the tracking upfront and doesn’t get used in Mastering, but does get used sometimes in mixing.

I operate out of my home studio which provides low overhead, my “studio” is where my band rehearses and where I Mix and Master, I also bring bands in occasionally to track in my basement, but it a little tight.

I wonder what y’all’s thoughts are, I love doing all these things but feel like, I’m just kinda stuck treading water and not swimming toward a destination.

author: Eric Martin
content: I still go to other studios to finish my band stuff when it comes to tracking because I need to stay in “guitar player” headspace and not producer/guitar player/engineer headspace.

Greg Wells said in some interview that he’s downright embarrassed to this day by one of his really successful early releases he was a part of. May have even been his first hit as a producer — I can’t remember the specifics. But he also said he’s noticed that reality being a through-line in the industry for a lot of people. As Cian said, good to have “I love this!” as the target for any and every gig, but there are a lot of cooks in our collective kitchens. 

The longer I do this, the more grace I give to a lot of what I think are lame/bad/wrong decisions in music I hear. Some of it is taste, sure, but I also have to remember there were most likely a lot of opinions to appease on any given song.

author: ehutton21
content: But if you’re actually cold on them because you’re not feeling the work, I think you’ll endear a lot of respect if you say “hey I think you’re a cool person but this music just isn’t something that resonates with me, and I’m not going to give you my best work if I’m not feeling the project.” And that’s where you could maybe refer them to someone who would be willing to take them on. author: jordanmcleod_io
content: i like to do 3 hour demo sessions and see what comes out. knowing i’m on the clock forces me to focus on getting the ideas out instead of spending so much time on the details of the sounds. a lot of the times is just a basic drum loop, some keys or guitar, and a bassline.. plus whatever vocal melody/lyrics i can come up with. i create at least an a and b part, sometimes c if flows out naturally. i make myself arrange a full song from those different parts even if each part isn’t “complete”. then later on i can go back and have a great starting point to focus on some of the more detailed things.

The guys who produced “No Problem” for chance the rapper used entirely stock tools, mike dean and a bunch of other mixers I see are routinely skipping pro-q for the stock EQ. Just the other day when i was mixing a demo track i recorded, I made myself use stock plugins for about 80% of it cause I still had a lot of production work to do but it could use some cleaning. Honestly, the mix sounded just as good (if not better) and my production work went over better because latency wasn’t an issue and I didn’t have to worry about committing.

author: peterlabberton
content: Lotta good answers so far so I’ll just say +1 to the above. I’ll *also* add that the ceiling for what you can earn here in music is *way* higher. I moved from San Francisco 5 years ago. I had a good thing going there and was well connected to a bunch of other full-time working music folks—you can charge way more in LA for your services than you can just about anywhere else. I’m now easily charging double what my friends back in the Bay Area are, in large part due to the environment in LA and the available work. Now, getting hired is an entirely different thing, but it’s worth remembering that, if and when you make the connections to start getting regularly hired, you can make enough to easily outpace the cost of living. (Caveat: I’m speaking as a mixer/engineer/drummer—if you’re more on the songwriting/spec production/artist side… 🤷🏻‍♂️)

author: ehutton21
content: I think it’s important to remember the dollar today>dollar tomorrow point is true in the context of a choice between two deals/options that are on the table (but even then, you have to do the math to make sure! Just because you have a deal with $1500 now versus $4000 in a year doesn’t mean that you should take $1500 now, unless you need that kind of capital). To apply that logic to situations beyond the time value of money isn’t the whole picture: that law of economics only compares value, it doesn’t tell us that concentrating labor for short term gains yields the best possible business model. By that logic, there is an argument that everyone’s best business decision is to forego longterm relationship building, knowledge acquisition (which is like R&D for producers), and strictly focus on maximizing immediate sales (which could look like everyone hopping on beatstars, fiverr, and enginears) which would diminish resources like this very discord, and probably a lot of reputations too!

author: timwatt_
content:
Pretty basic question but how do you guys archive production/songwriting sessions?

An artist wants to use a production of mine from 2017 and when I opened up the session to run off the multitrack many of the plugins didn’t load. I’ve been able to download/upgrade/fix most of the heavy movers but some can’t be installed on the current OS. Main culprits are the original Neutron and Vocalsynth (which I was using a lot at the time).

I figure that in this situation I’m going to have to recreate some sounds (which is fine as I’ll be reproducing some of the more dated elements anyway) but it got me thinking about future proofing sessions going forward. It’s made me even consider not using certain plugins in my productions if it’s likely they won’t be supported in the future (*cough* izotope).

I’m sure the solution is as simple as ‘print a multitrack when done’ but if anyone has any other thoughts I’m all ears!

author: Jodonny
content: Splice isn't putting limiting and normalization on the downloaded files, you're hearing what the producer intended there. The browser is crazy loud because they've normalized all the samples up to near 0db to be as loud as possible. Try using the "normalization" feature in Logic's output and it'll make sense.

author: Jodonny
content: But my point is every pack/producer's samples are different, it's not just a Splice thing (and I'm here talking about how I don't want to use Splice...). Some people like that clipped sound. If you don't like it you can find other packs.

author: Zack Hames
content:
A big turning point for me was my consultation with Unfuck your studio. Rauri and spider chatted with me for I think a couple of hours and it was instrumental in me pushing myself. 

They essentially told me to be in more high stakes situations. Rauri asked how often am “I the smartest or most experienced person in the room?” In regards to producing, etc. almost always - which is the exact problem because it’s not like I’m out here making hits. They were telling me that by working at this lower level, turning C- bands into B- bands, or D+ projects to C+ projects, wasn’t going to get me where I wanted. I need to get in the rooms with higher stakes.

It took a while but that’s exactly what happened. I’m working with people who are insanely talented musicians and writers, some of which are incredible engineers in their own right, but they do their tracking with me now

author: Adam Thein
content:
I have quite a few collaborators who press really small amounts of vinyl (100-300) just to have it, as sort of a legitimizing thing if that makes sense.  They usually are lucky to break even on production costs.

Another challenge with vinyl is scaling up.  Lead times are insane now and you are taking a risk by not pressing enough if you have the demand there.  The hardcore fans are willing to pay and often a second hand market comes up where the price skyrockets and none of the money finds its way back to the artist.

But yeah it really is a cool artifact to me, and something worth keeping alive in my opinion.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
**Keyboard players (and songwriters) of LWMR:** I need to seriously up my keyboard chops this year. 

I’ve been keyboard catting my way through life up to now - mashing out left hand root notes and RH triad shapes to get the rhythm and feel down, then fixing the notes / adding removing midi.  Fine by myself, but infuriating for anyone else in the room. 
 
I’m going to be in some (mostly writing) situations where that’s not going to cut it - I need to be much more fluent.

What are some efficient ways to get there? I’ve tried putting myself through the school of YouTube, but I haven’t found a course prescriptive enough to keep me focused and on track - just loads of disparate technique tutorials, and I don’t know what order to take them in. Also took some lessons, but cost and scheduling were unsustainable.

If it helps, my theory and reading were at one point strong and can probably be dredged back up if needed.

author: ALXCPH
content: At least for me and I know for a lot of people, a lot of the greatest musicians, it’s their so-called incorrect techniques combines with their taste that’s gives them their sound. If not we’d all just sound like midi instruments 🤪

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Thank you Noah, but you’ve been hoodwinked! Sadly I only played one good bar of that repeating right hand rhythmic figure on one finger, edited and looped it, then programmed everything else around it. It took ~15 minutes to make 2 passable minutes of piano - I want to be slimming that down to 3-4 mins (a couple of passes, edit, 82% quantise, profit).

The one “technique” that’s been consistently useful to me on other instruments is recording parts. It’s only then that I can really hear what I’m doing well and what needs work.

So good shout, thank you. I’ll fit that in to my song learning routine.

author: Barbara
content:
They came back with 10 PAGES of comments, with stuff regarding other takes we might had (I forgot to mention, but it was a deal that once I've sent the files for them to continue production, every take and edit was correct and accepted by all of them, in order to commit and make decisions... specially, because it was an edit nightmare, but mostly because I knew they weren't experient and it would be hard to finish anything if we kept having too many options to chose from - which we hadn't. That was indeed the most polished takes and performance they had, and it still needed A LOT of care), a list of reference tracks that wasn't even close in anything to what we had or could ever have, and me wanting not to jump in again on all of that. And during this, I had other people hearing my mix (colleagues) that were harsh on the way they gave feedback - not criticising, I knew it was shite, but I think it was the right thing at the wrong time for me.

At this point, I was struggling so bad with imposter syndrome, I was seriously considering quitting and getting the blues about the process, not happy with the result but not sure how I could do any better. And yes, I was working on other stuff, but this project was sucking all my energy and mood.
Feeling like a fraud and a failure. There is no sugar coating it.
But most of all, I wanted to make it work for the band. I wanted to give them my best, and wanted really hard that my best could be the best for them. So I kept going, and entered into it. 

Version 2... 7 pages of comments, all on different stuff that I thought we already nailed on the first version, since there was absolutely no comment on those things before... 

Oh, by the way, by this time, I was still waiting on some dry tracks from the producer, to make moves that the band asked for on the first version review.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Let the man sing if he wants to! 🤠 I’d argue that having some musical experience/intuition is 10/10 times not a bad thing. No matter what your job is in the music making process. 

Sure it’s not the engineers job to give advice. But if an artist asks when they are stuck with something being able to communicate at the same language is never a vibe breaker. I’d even argue it could enhance “vibes” or confidence, as long as what is being said makes contextual sense. 

It might be different where you are or at your level. But where I am (lower level 😂) who ever is in the room is involved. And if the process is being respected. I’ve been in so many sessions where I’ve recorded an artist and they ask for a harmony advice, or even if we are vocal producing, being able to quickly sing a line to quickly reference a point in the song is so much. Faster then having to look for it.
