author: Zach Hughes
content: I found it works really well as a tool to bounce ideas and approaches off of. Seems a far way off from doing the work for you for more complicated programs, but chat gpt + some critical thinking skills seems pretty powerful. The conversation threads are very meandering and I would have to rephrase instructions up to a half dozen times sometimes before it understood what I was trying to do. It would provide a suggestion, I'd do it and get an error, share the error, and it would correct itself. Several of those loops in a row. A buddy of mine who is a computer programmer was telling me about a peer of his who created a program that prompts chat gpt to write code then automatically feeds any errors back into chat gpt and it keeps looping and looping and looping until the code works. Pretty cool stuff

author: LAPhill
content:
Not exactly my point. AI is going to take awhile to replace various aspects of what we do. So creators can drive where THEY see value, in hopes of steering the tech. If everyone here hates timing drums, and an AI can come along to do it while maintaining groove and feel, perfect transients, etc., that saves time and is worth something.

Whether or not that's more valuable to the tech company than offering 50,000 bedroom producers the tools to make "pro-sounding" beats easier than with Splice.... probably not.

These scenes later splintered into U.K. funky (where I started producing ) that took New York house producers like Dennis Ferrer and Kerri chandler and gave it a little more bass and percussion ……and then Atlanta trap took over here for a good few years until a few years back until today with the youngers like 808 melo, chencs, ghostie etc creating U.K. drill from Chicago drill which has now gone back to yall in America via pop smoke as Brooklyn drill . author: Deleted User
content:
I think the bigger question is the lack of money in recording business. 

No tangible way of making real money off of it for most people except those who are landing sync placements, which can really be anyone. The way I see it is sync placement is fulfilling more of the utility aspect of art, while making records for people to listen to is a more artistic endeavor in service of the people that listen to the records. But the reality is that everyone’s streaming and that doesn’t pay. Even with the biggest success- it won’t make money correspondent to the level of success. 

Budget for record production is now more of a PR for their shows or tours. (As far as what I can tell)

So why in a sane mind would anyone spend money on making it other than for their own satisfaction? It’d be insane to see making records as business investment unless you’re really aiming for sync in mind. But then, what most of us fell in love with are the amazing records that we grew up listening to. Maybe a song from a movie occasionally, but probably not quite a track from sports spot nor a jingle. 

At this point, is there really a way to monetize real money from records other than sync? If there can be, what would that be?

author: spectrummasters
content: @Deleted User  and @masteredbyjack ....thanks for your perspectives gents. I dont disagree with you that what you are both describing is true for where we are at currently and have been for some time. im trying (badly) to not promote my view as opposed to the views shared by the engineers in the discussion im referencing....but fwiw , in 2022 the global recording revenue i think was around 20 billion dollars. Thats a lot of dough. Im not a socialist....im not against the free market.......the discussion was centred around the growing leverage engineers have in the industry and whether that is being marketed effectively to increase the price of the skilled labour engineers provide. When i first started getting indie production deals i was adviesd in the music business, when it comes to discussing deals, everyone's friends...when it comes to paying on those deals......no-one's friends....its only business. I have found this to be true and have no objection to it.

author: LAPhill
content:
I'm trying to zoom out here. Like, what is the actual revenue being brought in by the artists you're hoping to work with? Where is money to be made and who's making it? 

Picking a nice round number, if you're an engineer on an album that gets a million streams a year, that's something like $4000 for the artist. Hopefully they generate money from touring, but based on the album's services alone, how much could an artist reasonably pay if their ROI is $4k?

If the gamble is to get hooked up with a new artist who has the potential to break through, the producer's points on a hit is where real money could be made, right? So pricing yourself to get at many chances at the lottery would likely be more fruitful than a few extra hundred per gig, but it's a gamble. Between repeat clients and chance for a moderate hit, it seems like a better way to spend your time

All that said, as you pointed out, this ain't my lane.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I enjoyed getting caught up on this thread from the past two days. In case anyone is interested there's a book that @shaunobi shared about previously here called '*Chokepoint Capitalism*' that I believe provides an interesting context for some of the topics / ideas from this convo. I'm about halfway through it myself.

There has been a lot of talk here about there not being enough money entering into the top of the music industry, but far less talk about how little of the money that does flows towards the artists and producers of the art that drives the industry and culture.

The book makes a pretty compelling case that copyright law, antitrust law / enforcement (or lack thereof), regulatory capture, the consolidation of power in the music industry and formation of monopolies / monopsonies with anticompetitive flywheels has greatly contributed to the reality or perception by some that the average creative worker in this industry is getting less in return for the actual value they are putting in. I'm still sifting through it but do think it's worth a read / would make for an interesting addition to the discussion.

author: spectrummasters
content: Speaking of drum samples ......The drums from Rihanna’s umbrella are a logic Apple loop , it’s in everyone’s loop browser🤣 .: when it comes to samples . I started with an mpc . I built my kits from sampling my fav records and finding isolated hits. It’s an art and it takes love of the record......but I’d recommend going this way with it .....I think @Deleted User .....said it right. The internet is awash with sample packs that are just the same hits renamed. You can grab all the OG Roland and linn drum kits in seconds these days......and all the processed versions of them since . If  you sample things yourself you’re curating as you go and this will imo , make it different and valuable. D’angelo voodoo, Dre 2001; Wookie and James brown gave me all I needed for drums for the longest .

author: Deleted User
content: also lets you control things with more finesse. If you want to compress low mids of a synth but not for it to be clamped down- I put the detection on higher mid so it can let go of compression quicker. Only the attack portion of it is compressed as opposed to it being compressed the through the whole sustain

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Not sure where to put this so we’ll start here and maybe we can migrate it if it lands in any way

Had a great call last week with @Josh. We talked about a bunch of stuff but one of the themes we explored was the idea that one needs a “portfolio” of slick & great sounding work to get hired

Once you’ve decided that then it becomes the focus, and changes the way things feel and the way decisions about time, who you work with etc get made. Concepts like “I’ll suck it up and work for free but *then* I will have a singular “good track” for my portfolio”. Of course there are exceptions but it feels to me that there’s something very constricting and materialist about this way of being in the world. There can be a tension between what the artist wants or what the song wants to be and what makes you look “good” in your portfolio - they want mono and grimy but you want wide/lush/impressive

In our jam I proposed a kind of thought experiment, an end of the line or extreme of the “need portfolio” way of thinking…

So let’s say you are here, a young writer, producer, mixer. You’ve been doing it 3 or 4 years. You feel that one of the reasons you are not getting hired, getting shots or getting paid well is that there isn’t a body of work for a potential client to judge you by. Ok, here’s comes the magic trick. I’m going to grant you a genie wish portfolio! 5 killer tracks with  great collaborators. Not hot 100 #1 but the kind of work that you really feel would represent you best in the world. Boom. There it is…

So now what? You get some DMs and sessions start happening. But you’re not ready. You’re not fit for game day. You’re in over your head, and don’t have the fluency, the experience, the reps and the humblings that build a great music business pro. In short you’re not ready for the opportunities the genie wish portfolio granted you

There’s a perfect example happening right now. I’m mixing a few live songs for an artist with near a million followers who’s normally produced by one of my all time fav producers.

On my first pass, I didn’t try and ordain what I thought the artist would want (which is where this whole covnversation started) I did the absolute best I could to make it what I thought the absolute best it should be. author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
I had a fellow studio owner tell me one time that Dropbox changes audio in the files...   and guys,  I'm here to testify at the #nerd channel level:  that ain't true. Lol

But ...  user xp is crap and if that playback cause client conflict for you?  Kill it.  

Changing audio content though?  Not in my xp.  I'm partner in a sample library dev company, and we move about 25k to 50k samples per product through Dropbox.  Never has an artifact be "introduced" ...  it doesn't even effect metadata tags like iXML or bext. Certainly isn't changing a random sample in the PCM stream.

author: Deleted User
content:
there are few different ways (that I know of)

1) made with MIDI, with sample based instruments for acoustic stuff (strings, horns, guitars, etc)

2) FFT wizard-ry sampled and then iFFT to re construct sounds

3) AI training on instruments (analyzes formants, time domain information along with spectral information)


Combination of 1 & 3 have been bringing the best “sounding” results.

author: Matt Huber
content:
So, first of all, thanks to the buds here who appreciate what I’ve posted in the past.

Second of all, my thoughts on this:
 
I have a personal rule that I will NOT post anything that feels like EFFORT or out of a motivation to game the algo. If I’m “making content” and notice that I’m doing so out of a place that is less than genuine, I will just delete and move on. 

For me, the “mix tips” thing came out of a sincere place of excitement and passion. I would, as a growing mix engineer, stumble upon something that excited me, and I would find myself wanting to turn around to the people in the room to share…well, there’s almost never anyone in the room with me. So, I channeled that passion and excitement in a genuine way to share with the small community of mixers, mastering engineers and producers that I knew on IG. 

At the beginning of my career on to the middle of my career, that became a very fruitful source of business for me - people who followed me on IG, who enjoyed my posts, and began to view me as someone who MIGHT know a thing or two about mixing. 

As my career has developed and my clientele has growing, that has become less important, but it was absolutely pivotal in helping me build a deep bench of great clients, both indie and signed. 

But…I NEVER did it for that reason. It was always (and continues to be) a genuine result of my passion for what I do.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
@SoundsLikeJoe prolly better to move this here. 

that's not a good example for thepoint you're trying to make. 
that article would be defining "best" which is an abstract concept by nature. 
the word "producer" is a non abstract thing (persons) whose definition has changed over time within /because of of specific culture shifts. 

whether we like it or not culture defines words. trap music isn't trap music anymore. it used to refer to a very specific slice of black / hiphop /hood culture. now, it's an edm subgenre to a huge chunk of the world.  me not liking this fact doesn't make it not true.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Thinking about REFs today on foot of a revision. Awesome artist, A list mixer. Has huge sine bass notes in a few sections that were chattering a bit with the short iZotope maximizer release. This mixer uses the same limiter setting on every mix and I copy it and work from non limited mix, sometimes tweaking slightly

So bass distortion sounds cool to me, but more importantly it was in the REF. So to my mind it’s cool and in the artist’s signpost of intention …. But they wanted it clean (which was possible and pretty easy)

I guess the message and the reason for putting it in general is that we’re all under the gun with deadlines, and all through the process there can be a sense of it’s just a demo, just a producer ref,. just a mix ref …. we’ll nail it later. But each girl or guy downstream is picking up on intentions from the REFs

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
Is it worth bothering about sample clearance as an independent artist/producer who probably doesn't even have the means to do so? The way I see it, there are two possible outcomes: Your song doesn't blow up, no one cares enough to sue you, or the song does blow up, in which case the suing party will take a huge chunk, however, you'll probably still be left with a respectable sum after the fact
Think Juice WRLD Lucid Dreams, where Sting took 75% afaik or a similar number. 25% of Lucid Dream is still something I'd take without a second thought.

author: spectrummasters
content: Imho : so we used to have white labels for bootleg remixes / samples . If you’re building a long term career as a producer you might want to think about an alias / nom de plume for doing the uncleared sample thing . The consequences can be dire . The artist / label could order you to take down the entire song / reimburse them all of your earnings etc etc . The fugees nearly had to pull the score from the world’s record shops over the uncleared enya sample in one track on the album . The uncleared sample in ready or not gave wyclef a total nightmare

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Brings up an interesting point about latency and drivers...   So what latency do you work at?  

My RME setup can average 64 buffer samples (3ms)  in my primary scoring template of about 30 instances of Kontakt. When I was still using the RME AIO pci card the same template could run at 32 samples 1.5ms latency. Mixing is where it gets wacky.  Some of these plugins will cause massive latency beyond the audio driver and I can't use them while playing notes in with virtual instruments. 

Also...  direct monitoring is always key for acoustic instruments and the experience is near zero, so the original point wouldn't apply there (correct?)

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
With credits, is there a general consensus or definition on the distinction between  "producer" and "additional production" or is it always a case by case thing? Had a song I worked on (finished the production and did the mix) come out today. At the beginning of the project I had asked to be listed as a producer and mixer but realized when it came out, that the artist had listed himself as the producer and me as additional production/instrumentation, and mixer. The artist is a really good and longtime friend and I am going to just talk to him and ask that he fixes the credits (and will start making written agreements before all of my projects) but I am curious if there is any broader context that could help how I approach the conversation? 

Not super critical to the main question but here are some specifics of my situation: Artist wrote the song, and recorded some basic tracks (drums, vox, guitar). We then worked on it in my studio and I played more instruments (bass, guitars, keys, lap, steel, percussion). We then finished it remotely a few months later. Sent the Ableton production session back and forth a few times times and then I prepped and exported the files myself and mixed it in Protools. And I had to do what I would consider a fair amount of heavy lifting in the mix: song was pretty complicated and recorded at home so I ended up do doing a lot of clean up, some tuning, and a lot of sound shaping and effects. All that to say, this case feels pretty cut and dried but I am curious to know what types of work would appropriately fall under “additional production” and what is standard in the industry. Thanks!

author: Zach Hughes
content: Others can chime in but I think what would be appropriate is for you and the artist both to be credited as a producer. No need to slice it up.

author: stewart_hidalgo
content: Would second this. A lot of artists view being a producer as a vital part of storytelling and marketing.

author: EliHeathMusic
content: The main reason I was planning on bringing this up with the artist is because we had initially agreed on roles and credits before I started working on the song (just not in writing because he's a close friend and it didn't seem necessary at the time).  And I agreed to do the project and set my rate (offered a pretty significant friend discount) under the premise that I would be credited in a certain way. I totally understand that some artists want to be the only producer on their projects and if I was ghost producing a song for someone I would have probably charged a lot more. Either way, that doesn't seem like something that an artist gets to decide on their own after the song has already been completed. In my case I think it was just an honest mistake or he forgot or we had a miscommunication and its an easy thing to check in about and resolve. But it just made me wonder going forward if there is a clearer distinction between the two roles.

author: markmaclure
content:
I think Rick Rubin producing “Under The Bridge” was a masterclass in what I’m trying to understand. Maybe? I think he understood the point of view of RHCP better than they themselves did. He found a little piece of magic and somehow got the band to let go of their prior conceptions of their identify and record the song. Some Jedi shit for real. 

How do I do that? Should I do that? How should we as producers think about point of view when creating for/with artists? To what extent should we be involved in crafting the point of view? What should we do when an artist has potential but is lacking a distinct point of view? What is even is point of view?

Any thoughts would be welcome.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
I personally like pushing creative limits and tend to be very open about that when working with folk. I don't force it but because of being so open about it there are artist I mix for for example that only send me dry vocals cause they like what i do.  or I get producer /artist that will send me a rough and tell me to go wild and we'll edit and arrange later. 

some artist hand me their writings / poems to help them convert into lyrics. some I'll help edit stuff as we're recording.

our  job is to do what we  think is best for the song. that may involve pushing the artist sometimes but putting yourself in a position that allows them to receive that push is most important  i.e your relationahip w them.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah I'd also recommend pitching yourself or finding artist that you think are open to giving you more creative control or pushing back. I've been actively looking and reaching out to folk and interacting over the last year or so and a lot of them have started slowly reaching out to me for specific things, even if they already have a producer on deck. 

if that's the work you want more of now, go find it and get it. it won't find you until after you set things in place

author: itaylerner
content:
2 cents: I think it’s a “stars have to align” kind of thing (That’s why there’s a million artists but only 1 Beyoncé and 1 Post Malone) That combo of unique pov + excellent artistic taste + ability to express it all… it’s rare, to say the least.

I personally think, generally speaking, that a producers job is less about helping an artist craft their pov and more about supporting them in their process of uncovering and expressing it, Unless you’re extreeemely close with that artist. it’s really their job, as a human first, to process their experiences and develop their unique perspective. To become the most whole version of themselves, imho. 

Your job as a producer is to create a safe and encouraging space where they can explore and express it, say scary things, move forward in their ideas. It’s also your job to then facilitate the process at every stage, musically and otherwise, to make sure the execution is as good as it can possibly be. But the artist is the artist, it all comes from them at the end of the day.

author: kieronmenzies
content: In my experience, every artist has a very specific "point of view" with varying degrees of how well they know and/or express it. Sometimes we're in the studio with very specific goals in mind. For example: to sound like the the musical equivalent of the artist's Pinterest board, to sound like two of the artist's favorite artists had a baby together, to sound like the last album but different, or just to make our own version of an already-established style of music. On the other hand, sometimes we're searching and digging and discovering to see what happens. In these production sessions it may seem like there are no goal posts -- the goal is there but it's just not readily apparent. Maybe the artist doesn't seem like they even know what they want but they do and they'll know it when they hear it. And then once (if) you get to that aha! moment, it's like hitting something hard when digging for treasure in the sand. Maybe it's just a rock, or maybe it's coprolite or maybe, just maybe it's a chest full of gold coins which you can then hand over to the labels, managers, lawyers and streaming services while you keep a couple of the remaining fragments of copper for yourself.

author: samvalentine
content:
Hey, I’m not sure where to post this exactly, but I had an interesting experience the other day that I’d like to share with the group and hopefully get some perspective on.

I was touching up a track with a producer friend at the end of a writing session. Vocals and guitar recorded over a 2track beat. I typically throw a Waves L2 on my master, just to bring up the level for the rough bounce, never doing much more than a dB or two of gain reduction. In this case I had the threshold of the L2 set at -3.4. The producer said try -3.5, then back to -3.4, then -3.5… flipping back and forth seeing what he liked more. I couldn’t hear a difference. (I should say that we weren’t in a well treated room, working on some mid sized genelecs. It’s a  setup neither of us is super familiar with.) He decided -3.4 was better and I was in disbelief that he could even hear a difference. I asked if I could do a blind test to see if he could tell which setting was which. He closed his eyes and I switched back and forth a bunch of times before landing on a setting, and he called it correct three times in a row. He said he could hear something in the kick drum but couldn’t explain more than that.
I need a sanity check. I know my ears aren’t hall of fame, but I’m still in disbelief that he was able to tell a .1dB difference in volume on the limiter.

author: kieronmenzies
content: Me personally, Yeezus was the last album that I was super moved by and I've never really had much of a desire to revisit any of his stuff, as brilliant as it is (though I might try after this convo). But on this topic, I find it hard/impossible to completely 100% enjoy a piece of work after the artist has done something disagreeable, taken a public downfall or occasionally if I had a negative personal experience with them. Even though I might intellectually appreciate the beauty of the work, my heart just feels a slight bit of ick -- akin to that feeling of trying to enjoy a meal that you know is super delish but you burned your tongue on a hot cup of coffee the day before. So I’ll just end up choosing to listen to something else instead. This also makes me intensely appreciate my past experiences with the art. I don’t think I’ll ever enjoy it the same way again but I’m so glad I was able to completely enjoy Puff Daddy productions, R. Kelly songs, Woody Allen’s movies, Bill Cosby’s comedy, and Kanye West’s early albums when they were coming out and having their day. I’m resolved that it was a time in my life and in the universe and that time might be over now. Kinda like the ex-girl that you remember fondly but would never ever ever go back to.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think there’s a danger in assuming those that are successful didn’t have it hard.
2 quick stories that have shaped my career:

very early on when I was recruited to play in a band in Australia. Sold my car, got rid of my apartment, and flew out to Melbourne. Band had a moment but I got tossed out just as the song was going number 1. Had no money to get home, no where to stay, and was literally 23 living on our producers couch in a country about as far from home as possible. And I called my pop, basically telling him how bummed/scared/fucked I was. And he goes “you know, I just got off the phone with **** (a very famous actor friend of ours). If there’s anyone that had it all, you’d think it was him. Big career, wife on the cover of sports illustrated swimsuit edition, fans everywhere. But it turns out his Dad just passed, his wife is cheating on him, and if this new show doesn’t get picked up they might lose the house they just bought. EVERYONE has their share of crap they have to deal with, give or take, no matter how easy it looks from the outside. Life isn’t about what happens to you, it’s about how you deal with what happens to you. Figure out a way to make the most of what’s going on”. For some reason, knowing that EVERYONE’s life sucks to some degree, was immensely helpful in getting me back on my feet.

The other was a year or two later, when I started tuning vocals for Rob Cavallo. One of his wrecking crew of session musicians had been in a band with a huge hero of mine, who had sadly took his own life mid way through making his second record. I asked the guy if there was anything he could tell me about working with said hero, and he said “he was the best musician I’ve ever met. Whatever instrument you played he was better at it than you were within 10 minutes of picking it up. But he seemed to think he was the only guy that ever got a raw deal from the music industry”.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Snares or other sounds, I do have loose process that helps me move keep momentum and focus.

TLDR; It’s a contextual balancing act that takes both the context of the music and the studio environment into account.

Music Context

Phase 1 | Production
- 🔑 Everything will be refined later, so I focus on Momentum > Perfection.
- I feel the core energy of inspiration behind the track and go through sounds with the intention of finding one that captures the essence of the finished vision. Doesn’t matter if it’s excellent at this stage.

Phase 2 | Post-Production Mix
- 🔑 I revisit sounds with the intention to sculpt an emotionally enhancing space for the music to live in (small venue, living room, arena, efc).
- Refine sounds while keeping initial energy in mind, but you can focus more creativity on ‘mixing’ than ‘production’ (at least how my mind perceives them)
- Will likely need to replace a part of the snare stack, but now that more of the tracks vision has bridged the gap between vision to reality it’ll be easier to find a proper pocket and vibe for things. 
- Because that initial sound resonated with me, I’ll try plug-in sculpting before replacing, but I tend to add / replace the sound that emulates the rattle under the snare at this stage + add dimension for the emotional space I’m building.
- 🗒️ Sometimes a diff sample can come with these things off the bat no tweaking needed, its rare though.

author: spectrummasters
content:
…yeah the independent producer community backlash has been growing for the last few years against him already . 

There’s a discussion in my wheelhouse culture at the moment (london street music creators ) about whether the real value  of a project is about numbers / popularity or moving the culture . The further the “industry “ progresses into AI , for the sake of numbers , imho the more the value moves into cultural / underground art . 
Street music stories are about a common or represented experience . We want to hear the street poetry

If you take timbos hiphop midlife crisis and combine it with soulless number based work , I don’t think it’s likely to resonate with the culture .   This is why I think he’s likely to catch an L . 

Even the new clips release is being met with , okay you’re 50 and still rapping about coke ? 

….there an element of corny creeping in as the genre ages 

On the flip side, I think a whole new genre is gonna happen soon . Where’s there’s yin there will be yang

I had an artist I felt was limiting our results because he insisted he loved my shitty first draft of the production and it felt like he didn’t even want to hear my ideas past a certain point. Hence the rushedness you said you’ve witnessed, an urgency to get ideas in before demo-itis solidifies.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Yeah that makes sense. Thanks for the advice. The question is never ‘should I persist’ - Which is almost why I’m afraid. I feel like no matter what her and I are both locked in, and when someone else trusts me like that I want to be sure I can do my part in giving back in that dynamic.

It’s hard to weigh short term wins/losses vs long term wins/losses at this time cus I’m in the thick of it.

When reflecting, I know I always did my best to communicate as honestly as I could in every moment, and was transparent about every decision and my thought processes along the way. I’ve had many wins, but going a long period without financial wins has made me question the judgement I have when navigating everything.

“Winning” to me is a culmination of things that can be summed up as living authentically while positively contributing to the world and lives of others. It helps fight of the tendrils of negativity I feel coming from so many angles of the outside world, especially in the last decade.

I don’t exactly know what I’m asking. Or want. I’m looking to process these feelings and synthesize them into a new level of awareness as I move forward with what I’ve learned being integrated into my subconscious.

Sometimes being around others, or hearing their experiences and takes, helps me get angles of things in a way that I can piece together for a rough draft of what will become the lesson that I carry with me moving forward, regarding this topic at this time.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I’m late to this, but wanted to say my part that I navigate DAWs based on the mindset of the workflow I’m intending to get into.

If I needa hit a new track quick to get a vibe set, FL Studio is amazing for quick production and quickly transforming the studio into a different vibe, but if I need to do a bunch of vocal takes and/or deep mixing juggling chains and transforming that vibe into a captured piece, especially those meant to become a product, I find Pro Tools Ultimate the absolute 🐝s 🦵s for that.

-

They may have patched it and this is old news, but I know FL can’t handle as much CPU and it used to run off of one processor, so my quad processor CPU can’t handle more than 20 tracks in FL, whereas I can I have 200+ tracks on Pro Tools and still run smooth (utilizing freeze and stuff too, which FL doesn’t have) so yeah.

In the end, once a threshold of quality for a tool is passed, it’s a matter taste based preference, and I find my taste varying with projects and my two DAWs capture all the different intentions I find myself having between the two different UIs / Workflows

content: Huh. Where do you see them? I only see the usual composer and producer credits in the sidebar.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Second. I used to teach at a music production school where I had to teach DAWs and related concepts to beginners from the ground up and it dramatically improved my own understanding of the fundamentals because I was being asked questions by students that illuminated every single thing that I didn't fully understand. Taking the time to teach is a great way to firm up your own understanding.

I frequently talk to myself and explain things out loud like I'm speaking to someone else. In fact ten minutes ago I *just* explained discipline out loud like I was speaking to my (nonexistent) stubborn child. It forces me to find an elegant approach and make sure I truly understand what I think I know.

author: EliHeathMusic
content: I've been reevaluating my file naming/archiving/deliverables conventions this week and have been trying to come up with a standardized way to keep track of album sequence (I mainly produce and mix). It seems tough because these things can change last minute but also I find it nice to include the info when there is a defined order. For mastering folks, do you have a favorite way to receive info about the track sequence (i.e. each track gets a number in front of it, separate PDF with this info, email message)?
